title: Live 1976
label: Galactic Zoo Disk
description: This rare 1976 live recording shows the experimental folk musician in uncharacteristically lucid form, tying together unlikely influences into fluid, unusual compositions.

title: The Lost Entrance of the Just
label: Handmade Birds
description: Following last year's excellent Eleven Fingers, the mysterious Finnish duo trades the frisson of black metal, post-punk, and pop for a subtle union of gorgeousness and ghoulishness.

title: Split Cranium
label: Hydra Head
description: Aaron Turner of Isis and Jussi Lehtisalo of legendary Finnish shape-shifters Circle join forces for a collection of full-throttle crust punk.

title: Quakers
label: Stones Throw
description: Portishead's Geoff Barrow assembles a 40-plus-person cast ranging from hip-hop vets to obscure MCs for an indie rap recording that's engaging in spite of its heavily fractured structure.

title: Rock and Roll Night Club EP
label: Captured Tracks
description: The artist formerly known as Makeout Videotape releases an EP of unsettling soft rock that mixes freaky sleaze with a surprising dose of swooning sensitivity.

title: Strange Grey Days
label: Manimal Vinyl
description: On its self-titled debut, this Vancouver "garage soul" band does a faithful, playful recreation of 1960s girl-group sounds, filtered through proudly grimy production.

title: Nightmare on E Street
label: self-released
description: The rising D.C. rapper's newest bears some worrying marks of encroaching industry bullshit, but by and large, it's a generous helping of what made Fat Trel noticeable in the first place.

title: Let the People Speak
label: Sonic Unyon
description: Violet Clark has described her second album with husband Frank Black as "doggystyle," but it doesn't even qualify as masturbation.

title: A Wasteland Companion
label: Merge
description: M. Ward's seventh album sounds as gloriously refined as ever, but pairs uncharacteristic sweetness with a mismatched bitter streak for a record with a shaky sense of self.

title: Much Ado About EP
label: Mon Amie
description: The San Franciscan jangle-poppers' final release significantly peps up their previously downtrodden approach for a winsome EP.

title: Dusk | Subside
label: Relapse
description: The Melbourne metal band forges a strong bridge between two of its members' past in cultish doom group diSEMBOWLMENT and a more rock-oriented focus on the future.

title: Harmony, Melody and Style: Lovers Rock and Rare Groove in the UK
label: Soul Jazz
description: Soul Jazz's latest compilation focuses on British lovers rock, the softer, more feminine counterpart to the politicized roots reggae that soundtracked radical social and racial events in 1970s and 80s Britain.

title: Our Love Is Hurting Us EP
label: Tri Angle
description: On his second EP in as many years, Christopher Dexter Greenspan goes for another swim in witch house's corpse-laden waters.

title: Boys & Girls
label: ATO
description: The much-hyped, Jack White-feted Alabama garage band's debut finally arrives a significant amount of time after its completion, working to their benefit and detriment.

title: Transistor Rhythm
label: 50 Weapons
description: On his debut LP, UK juke/bass producer Antony Williams is still taking cues from Chicago's South Side veterans, but for the first time it feels like he's building something of his own.

title: An Letah
artist: Janka Nabay and the Bubu Gang
label: True Panther
description: Two years after his Bubu King EP, the N.Y.-based Sierra Leone musician offers a whiplash set of electrified bubu backed by NYC locals like Highlife's Doug Shaw and the band Skeletons.

title: Songs
label: Downtown
description: The Leeds producer's sophomore LP is a nasty carnival of electronic pop that giddily hops between styles like a broken radio.

title: De Vermis Mysteriis
label: E1
description: Following the glossy sheen of 2010's Snakes for the Divine, High on Fire get back to doing what they do best: sweaty, thrashing, chipped-tooth stoner metal.

title: Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded
label: Cash Money
description: Much of Nicki Minaj's ambitious second LP sweats with a too-big-to-fail desperation. At its best, she innovates with the playful abandon of prime-era Missy Elliott or Busta Rhymes. But in her quest to avoid becoming just another female rapper, she settles for being just another pop star.

title: I Don't Want to Die
label: NNA Tapes
description: The Burlington, Vt., singer-songwriter's new album finds him refining his pop vision, splashing it with touches of New Age pensiveness and moments that topple into dissonance.

title: Vattnet Viskar
label: Broken Limbs
description: This small-town New Hampshire black metal band's auspicious debut EP manages to marry ambition and efficiency without a misstep.

title: Iradelphic
label: Warp
description: Deciding he was "bored of computers," the restless English producer's latest album (featuring guest vocals from Martina Topley-Bird) offers his most drastic shift to date.

title: I Love You, It's Cool
label: Hometapes
description: The Brooklyn trio follows 2009's Beast Rest Forth Mouth with a record that's admirable in large part because its ambitions are as subtle and difficult to quantify as its pleasures.

title: A+E
label: Parlophone
description: On his raw and visceral eighth solo LP, Graham Coxon takes us back to when he was revered as Blur's experimental weirdo.

title: Other People’s Problems
label: Fat Cat
description: The London band, four filmmakers-turned-musicians named after the founder of Surrealism, offer ambiguous politics on their buzzed about debut.

title: New Wild Everywhere
label: Nettwerk
description: The Canadian folk-rock band's fifth record introduces a semi-permanent lineup and marks the first time the Tony Dekker-led group's recorded in a proper studio.

title: Young Man in America
label: Wilderland
description: The ambitious Vermont-born folk singer and Bon Iver collaborator offers "a meditation on a theme" that pulls off the difficult feat of feeling political without ever being didactic.

title: lowFLOWs: The Columbia Anthology ('91-'93)
label: Columbia Legacy
description: This collection assembles the post-Minutemen trio's two albums released on Columbia, an EP, and an assortment of extras, offering a generous overview of the group's loose-limbed, slightly lopsided rumble.

title: Wonky
label: ACP
description: Orbital's first album in eight years, featuring a collaboration with Zola Jesus, finds the Hartnoll brothers doing what they've always done best.

title: Locked Down
label: Nonesuch
description: Dan Auerbach of the Black Keys produced the New Orleans legend's newest, a weird-ass mix of grotty funk and R&B.

title: H.N.I.C. 3
label: self-released
description: A year after his release from prison, Mobb Deep's Prodigy offers his latest and most high-profile attempt at finding his footing in A$AP Rocky's New York.

title: Mouseman Cloud
label: Fire
description: The beyond-prolific Guided by Voices frontman's first solo LP since January's Let's Go Eat the Factory was recorded with an emphasis on wordplay.

title: Year Zero OST
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Combining edits of their best songs with five new pieces, the Vancouver psych-rock band offers a nine-song soundtrack for the post-apocalyptic surf film Year Zero.

title: Kill for Love
label: Italians Do It Better
description: Chromatics' first album since 2007's stunning Night Drive is a 90-minute tour-de-force that gives their nocturnal foreboding a new sense of grandeur. Though long, Kill for Love is lushly atmospheric and replayable, with expansive interstitial tracks balancing its impressive clutch of gorgeous synth-pop singles.

title: Milo Goes to Compton
label: Art Fag
description: Naming her first LP after the 1982 debut by the Descendents (who she also covers), the one-woman Oakland band offers an amalgam of punk, garage, and 1960s girl group harmonies.

title: Lightships
label: Geographic
description: On his solo debut, Teenage Fanclub's Gerard Love offers a lush, cerebral rendering of his other band's pop ethos with the help of past and present Fanclub members.

title: Both Lights
label: Leaf
description: Luke Wyland's latest endlessly resituates itself between towering chamber-folk, cyclonic Marnie Stern-style spazz, and orchestral psych.

title: Acousmatic Sorcery
label: XL
description: The gifted Chicago singer-songwriter and self-identified outsider artist makes his full-length debut with an often impressive collection of home-recorded material from the last several years.

title: Spooky Action at a Distance
label: Kranky
description: The Deerhunter guitarist/songwriter's fantastic second solo LP is unerringly tuneful and immediate, the sort of thing that seems unambitious until you step back and ask yourself just how many records actually manage to pull this off.

title: Grief Pedigree
label: Iron Works
description: The Brownsville MC's newest LP puts weight behind the wisdom of age and experience. Fittingly, it's the kind of record that takes a bit of experience to really sink in.

title: Come the Thaw
label: Profound Lore
description: Featuring Agalloch's Aesop Dekker on drums, this Bay Area band moves between doom metal and gentler 4AD-adherent epics on its sophomore LP.

title: Happy To You
label: Downtown
description: The Swedish trio, including the production duo Bloodshy & Avant (Britney Spears, Kelis, Kylie Minogue), offer springy electronic pop on their sophomore LP.

title: Hundred Waters
label: Elestial Sound
description: The Gainesville, Fla., quintet composes bewitching digital folk on its immersive debut.

title: Zammuto
label: Temporary Residence
description: Following the breakup of the Books earlier this year, Nick Zammuto's self-titled debut finds him singing and playing his heart out through an array of computer dressing.

title: Ariettes Oubliées...
label: Prophecy
description: On their second album, Alcest's somber comrades Les Discrets blend post-rock, dusky goth-pop, and the faintest shadow of black metal to create their own take on "French shoegaze metal."

title: Choreography
label: Tough Love
description: The London power pop band's debut recasts the exuberance of mid-1960s Beatles and Byrds as a manifestation of modern-day social anxieties and sleep-depravation-induced paranoia.

title: awE naturalE
label: Sub Pop
description: This Seattle neo-soul duo lent forcible female vocals to Shabazz Palaces' 2011 LP Black Up. Following a handful of self-released mixtapes, awE naturalE marks their proper debut.

title: Taylor Allderdice
label: self-released
description: Now a legitimate star, Wiz Khalifa offers a free mixtape named for his high school that attempts to reclaim what he sees as his.

title: LateNightTales, Vol. 2
label: Late Night Tales
description: The LateNightTales series asks artists to create a "late night" mix from their record collections. Belle and Sebastian's second contribution leans heavily on the 1960s and early 1970s, with occasional glimmers of modernity.

title: Transverse
label: Mute
description: This live recording from an improvisational performance by Throbbing Gristle's Chris Carter and Cosey Fanni Tutti and Factory Floor's Nik Colk Void has an unusual transformative energy.

title: Broda
label: Gala Drop
description: On Broda, the Portuguese group Gala Drop and Six Organs of Admittance's Ben Chasny make like a crack 1960's instrumental band wailing freely.

title: Illusion EP
label: Sub Pop
description: This Seattle band, featuring members of Fleet Foxes and Crystal Skulls, debuts with a five-song EP of tumbling acoustic fingerwork and gauzy group harmonies.

title: Seeds
label: SomeOthaShip Connect
description: The restless R&B auteur offers one of her most captivating statements, a deeply spiritual collection produced by Madlib.

title: Viva Hate
label: EMI
description: Morrissey's fascinating 1988 solo debut is the perfect subject for a deluxe reissue package, but Morrissey being Morrissey, that isn't what we got.

title: Listen, Whitey! The Sounds of Black Power 1967-1974
label: Light in the Attic
description: Focusing on the music and rhetoric of Black Power music at street level, this set places songs by artists like Gil Scott-Heron and the Last Poets alongside spoken word pieces from Stokely Carmichael and Dick Gregory.

title: The Revolution EP
label: Sub Pop
description: The more visceral side project of Alan Sparhawk's Low dips its toes into arena-ready 80s corporate rock with strange results.

title: Kenny Dennis EP
label: Anticon
description: The rapper who recently collaborated with Sufjan Stevens steps out with a concept EP that finds him rapping in his Kenny Dennis alter-ego, a character who loves to riff on Chicago sports and sausage and not a whole lot else.

title: Folila
label: Nonesuch
description: With contributions from Santigold, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Nick Zinner, and members of TV on the Radio, the Malian duo clearly have genre fusion in mind on their latest.

title: Don't Think
label: Astralwerks
description: This riveting DVD/CD set captures the energy and sensory overload of a Chemical Brothers show. It also showcases many of the finest moments from their catalogue.

title: Mirel Wagner
label: Friendly Fire
description: On her self-titled debut, the Ethiopian-Finnish singer-songwriter's stark doom-folk is in permanent flux between concerns of the soul and the desires of the flesh.

title: Earth
label: De Stijl
description: Marc Richter's fondness for altered records marks him as an evil twin of Philip Jeck or Leyland Kirby. His latest record as Black to Comm began as a film soundtrack, and the audio is a natural fit for a fabulous landscape full of piled corpses.

title: Sonik Kicks
label: Yep Roc
description: On Sonik Kicks, the legendary English songwriter makes use of electronic toys and a variety of production tricks.

title: Mixed Emotions
label: True Panther
description: Following an EP and various singles, the sunny Brooklyn synth-pop duo's full-length debut aims for the heart and the gut.

title: MDNA
label: Interscope
description: Madonna's 12th studio album, featuring collaborations with M.I.A. and Nicki Minaj, is the product of both a merger and a divorce.

title: Queen of the Wave
label: PID
description: The sample-happy Finnish electro-pop duo compose an "esoteric pop opera in three parts."

title: Blu Tops EP
label: BluRoc
description: This free five-song EP finds stalwart NYC producer Ski Beatz (Curren$y) teaming with Cam'ron, Vado, and upstart vocalist McKenzie Eddy.

title: Voices From the Lake
label: Prologue
description: As Voices From the Lake, Italian producers Donato Dozzy and Neel reinvent typical techno structures wholesale. Rarely can an album be this intimidatingly detailed, warmly inviting, and totally indifferent.

title: Beak & Claw
label: Anticon
description: Sufjan Stevens, the New York composer Son Lux, and the Anticon rapper Serengeti form an oddball trio on this EP.

title: Blue Chips
label: Unknown
description: Over the last six months, the Flushing native made the leap from promising character to one of the most hilarious and creative writers in rap. On Blue Chips, he's eminently quotable and savagely funny.

title: Rooms Filled With Light
label: Canvasback
description: The London baroque-rock band's sophomore album-- produced by Ben Allen (Merriweather Post Pavilion, Halcyon Digest)-- finds the group aspiring to darker and difficult territory.

title: Ice Level
label: Infinite Best
description: The genre-bending New York synth-funk septet create a glorious mess on their full-length debut.

title: Imikuzushi
artist: Oren Ambarchi | Keiji Haino | Jim O'Rourke
label: Black Truffle
description: This ecstatic third installment of Keiji Haino, Jim O'Rourke, and Oren Ambarchi's annual live meeting features ear-filling noise-rock that conjures metal, psych, and stoner rock.

title: Foreign Body
label: Kranky
description: Liz Harris (Grouper) and Jesy Fortino (Tiny Vipers) collaborated on this collection that effectively and purposefully combines their respective sounds.

title: The OF Tape Vol. 2
artist: Odd Future Wolf Gang Kill Them All
label: Odd Future
description: Incorporating all of Odd Future's members with surprising ease (not an easy task considering all the stylistic differences at play), The OF Tape Vol. 2 is the first thing in well over a year that will remind people of why they liked the L.A. skate punks in the first place.

title: The Host
label: Planet Mu
description: Under a new alias, the Irish producer Barry Lynn (aka Boxcutter) abandons beat-driven aggression for short, wafting pieces, and something more personal and psychedelic.

title: Leaving Atlanta
label: Douchemaster
description: Four years after his debut, the Atlanta power-pop songwriter returns with a sing-along sophomore LP dedicated to five friends who died in quick succession, most way too young.

title: Give You the Ghost
label: Totally Gross National Product
description: Gayngs mastermind Ryan Olson produced the debut from this double-drumming Minneapolis art-rock band fronted by ex-Roma di Luna singer Channy Leaneagh.

title: God's Father
label: Unknown
description: Lil B's newest is a 34-track opus that demands several sessions to take in. It's the latest proof that he hasn't finished telling us his peculiar story.

title: Between the Times and the Tides
label: Matador
description: The biggest solo production of the Sonic Youth co-founder's career features contributions from SY bandmate Steve Shelley, Wilco's Nels Cline, jazz organist John Medeski, guitarist Alan Licht, and former bandmate Jim O'Rourke.

title: Pipe Dreams
label: Tee Pee
description: This Bay Area shoegaze outfit features Nick Bassett of the black metal group Deafheaven. On their latest, they manage to establish a distinctive identity in a style that often relies on blurry facelessness.

title: Yesterday Was Lived and Lost
label: Lanark
description: New Build is the London trio of Hot Chip's Al Doyle and Felix Martin with engineer Tom Hopkins. On their debut, they capture the rare alchemy that first made Hot Chip so appealing.

title: Canto Arquipélago
label: Underwater Peoples
description: Antwerp-based collagist Lieven Martens makes contemporary New Age music that ripples with oceanic calm. This 35-minute collection is barely perceptible in places.

title: Lover Motion EP
label: Cutters
description: The Cut Copy bassist's first solo EP includes synth work from Cut Copy vocalist Dan Whitford and production by members of Architecture in Helsinki.

title: Silent Hour/Golden Mile EP
label: Warp
description: The Grizzly Bear and Department of Eagles member's first solo EP is a brief, majestic song cycle.

title: Trevor Jackson Presents Metal Dance: Industrial/Post-Punk/EBM Classics and Rarities 80 to 88
label: Strut
description: The man behind Playgroup lends his curatorial ear to music from the stiffer, meaner, moodier, fuglier world of 1980s industrial and its various offshoots, from the club-ready to the floor-clearing.

title: Decade
label: 100% Silk
description: Having broken through in the beat-driven sphere under his Ital alias with his excellent album Hive Mind, Daniel Martin-McCormick returns to the serrated edges of his noise-rock project Mi Ami.

title: Valentina
label: Scopitones
description: Though they are touring playing their 1991 album Seamonsters in its entirety, Leeds indie stalwarts the Wedding Present also have an album of new material, their first in four years.

title: Wreck
label: Alternative Tentacles
description: Unsane's sound is anti-evolutionary, almost masochistically so. For the past 20-odd years, both in their gruesome album covers and their often monosyllabically titled songs, they've explored only shades of grey, with spatterings of red. Their latest is one of their better ones.

title: Port of Morrow
label: Columbia
description: Five years after the moody Wincing the Night Away and two releases by his Broken Bells project, James Mercer returns to the Shins energized and with his songwriting prowess intact.

title: Baby
label: Island
description: The debut album by this Camden quartet demonstrates a studious appreciation of Clinton-era guitar rock. At times, they seem to want nothing more than to channel a 45-minute MTV rock block from 1995.

title: Everyday Grace
label: Hippos in Tanks
description: Incorporating elements of industrial music and a dissonant strain of early-1980s computer funk, producer Elon Katz explores themes of over-consumption, isolation, and claustrophobia.

title: Eternal Turn of the Wheel
label: Season of Mist
description: Controversy regarding politics has followed this mysterious Ukrainian band since its inception, and its latest LP offers no easy answers. But the album finds them at a musical peak, splitting the difference between Burzum worship and their folk-music leanings.

title: Bogota Rich: The Prequel
label: Maybach
description: This 13-song mixtape from the Maybach Music Group associate is disappointingly brief but also serves as a showcase for the rapper's fiendish creativity and technical ability.

title: Weed Forestin'
label: self-released
description: Lou Barlow's 1987 home-recorded indie folk cassette album is re-released yet again in a variety of formats with an hour of bonus material, and once again under the original Sentridoh name.

title: Form & Control
label: Tummy Touch
description: This NYC disco-pop outfit is indeed a band, and they do make occasional use of handclaps. Two out of three ain't bad.

title: Pretty Ugly
label: Hyperdub
description: Leon Smart's debut for Hyperdub offers an approach to dance music that looks askew, glances awry, and always moves out of kilter.

title: Frying on This Rock
label: Thrill Jockey
description: White Hills' third LP for Thrill Jockey in as many years finds these purveyors of brain-warping psychedelia arriving at Martin Bisi's studio with a few things worked out.

title: Closer EP
label: self-released
description: Cities Aviv collaborator steps out with an EP that pulls together many of-the-moment sounds-- quiet-storm R&B, Chicago house, 1970s funk, hypnagogic fuzz-pop-- in service of a concept album about getting it on.

title: 4Eva N a Day
label: self-released
description: The rapper's self-produced followup to last year's Return of 4Eva is heavy on the Southern rap exercises that point you away from his music and towards his heroes.

title: Phédre
label: Daps
description: Toronto's Phédre zig-zag through the sounds of classic rock, disco, post-punk, and gothed-out rockabilliy. They never stay in one place for long, but their melodic sensibility provides the thread.

title: Noctiluca
label: Post Present Medium
description: On their ambitious debut LP, past members of Finally Punk, Mika Miko, and Talbot Tagora make expansive music that's decidedly not punk.

title: The Shadow Gallery
label: Prosthetic
description: The Brooklyn hardcore/metal quintet's debut LP fuses the grandeur of Isis with the precision of Dillinger Escape Plan and injects it with unavoidable catchiness.

title: Where the Sands Turn to Gold
label: Rocket Girl
description: Jason DiEmilio, the Philadelphia musician behind Azusa Plane, took his own life in late 2006. This 2xCD + DVD collection offers an extensive look at the delicate, powerful guitar-derived drone work he created.

title: Always
label: Polyvinyl
description: You know what you're in for when you put on a new Xiu Xiu album, and the band's latest is a well-executed sampler of the magnified pain and horror we've come to expect from them.

title: Limo
label: MAD Dragon
description: This Brooklyn-via-Chicago electro duo's Limo consists of eight "movements" that bleed into one another and features vocals from Brazilian Girls' Sabina Sciubba.

title: Father Creeper
label: Sub Pop
description: The South African-born rapper/singer's second album, his first for Sub Pop, attempts to make a virtue of its own messiness.

title: Kingdoms
label: 100% Silk
description: The debut release from UK electronic artist (and La Roux keyboardist) Mike Norris is a collection of lush, deep DIY house music.

title: Muscle Car Chronicles
label: DD172
description: The New Orleans MC's experiment with rapping over a live funk-rock band stands as the first notable misstep of his rejuvenated career.

title: Rocket Juice and the Moon
label: Honest Jon's
description: Damon Albarn, former Fela Kuti drummer Tony Allen, and Red Hot Chili Peppers bassist Flea are the core of this album of West African-style funk and psychedelia.

title: Brain Pulse Music
label: Drag City
description: Ghost ringleader Masaki Batoh realizes a long-held dream to control music via brain waves, offering two such compositions amidst several improvised pieces.

title: Spaced Out
label: Mammoth Cave Recording Co.
description: The Calgary garage-pop band's warbly and reverb-heavy debut sounds like it was fueled by a sugar high.

title: Jewelry
label: Leaving
description: This free beat tape from Los Angeles sound collagist Matthew McQueen feels tailor-made for the unconscious.

title: Medicine Show #13: Black Tape
label: Stones Throw
description: A bit like the bookend to the original dozen installments of his Medicine Show series, Black Tape fuses rap a cappellas to Madlib's own hazy, no-fi dub-of-a-dub aesthetic.

title: We All Raise Our Voices to the Air (Live Songs 4.11-8.11)
label: Capitol
description: This 2xCD collection, the Decemberists' first live full-length in their decade-plus career, sets all their heady concepts, genre nods, and oddball experiments side by side.

title: Shangaan Shake
label: Honest Jon's
description: This 2xCD compilation features Theo Parrish, Demdike Stare, Ricardo Villalobos, and others doing remixes of 2010's Shangaan Electro: New Wave Dance Music from South Africa.

title: Faithful Man
label: Truth & Soul
description: The soul veteran builds out every song with towering horn arrangements, strings, and background vocals on an album focused on love, loss, and longing.

title: The Chap
label: Lo
description: The North London pop quintet follow last year's tongue-in-cheek greatest hits album We Are the Best with a collection that finds them immersed in feelings of insecurity, isolation, and anxiety.

title: Zoo
label: Matador
description: The Bay Area quintet's first record for Matador feels a long way from its powerviolence beginnings, with a cleaned-up sound and a focus on garage-rock hooks.

title: Ssss
label: Mute
description: Three decades after "Just Can't Get Enough", Depeche Mode's Vince Clarke and Martin Gore are back with 10 tracks of fierce, instrumental, no-bullshit techno.

title: Dispossession
label: Mexican Summer
description: The Brooklyn singer-songwriter weaves together British folk, improvised jazz, Indian raga, psych-rock, and a strange, unforgettable voice on his sophomore album.

title: The Aberrant Years
label: Sub Pop
description: The Australian noise-punk trio made compelling music from repetitive elements and narrow sonic parameters. The Aberrant Years collects the 1978-1989 lineup's complete output, including rare bonus tracks.

title: Careless World: Rise of the Last King
label: Interscope
description: Does the 22-year-old Compton-born MC have any other songs as good as his breakout "Rack City"? His sophomore album tries its damndest to answer this question in the affirmative.

title: Milk Famous
label: TBD
description: The Brooklyn-via-Columbia, Missouri sextet's Mike McCarthy-produced third album finds the group overestimating their ability to be interesting instead of likeable.

title: Love at the Bottom of the Sea
label: Merge
description: The record that marks the end of Magnetic Fields' self-imposed "no synth trilogy" is also the first Magnetic Fields album in a more than a decade that isn't organized around a formal limitation.

title: Scum.Collapse.Eradication
label: Nuclear War Now!
description: The vicious Canadian black/death metal band's fourth album is a challenge and a triumph.

title: King Con
label: V2
description: The New York singer-songwriter's debut is catchy and well-produced, but she rejects the ice-cream gloss and ambiguity of many other contemporary pop artists.

title: Untitled EP
label: Odd Future
description: Featuring production work from Juicy J, Flying Lotus, and the Alchemist, this is the first major release from the Odd Future camp to rely almost wholly on collaborations from outside its circle.

title: The Clearing
label: Dead Oceans
description: Recorded in Bon Iver's Wisconsin retreat, the North Carolina duo's third LP is broad and ambitious, documenting a challenging year with unprecedented studio gleam.

title: Wrecking Ball
label: Columbia
description: Bruce Springsteen's 17th studio album is an overtly political affair, with songs that tackle hypocrisy, greed, and corruption set to a musical backing of Civil War snares, gospel howls, and chain-gang stomps.

title: Best Behavior
label: Old Flame
description: The promising Brooklyn "synth-punk" trio's sophomore album is more accessible and enjoyable than their debut, but is it a legitimate leap?

title: Ain't Ain't Ain't
label: Anti-
description: Tim Fite's first album for ANTI- in years finds the Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter confusing being nice with being interesting.

title: Fatherland EP
label: Godmode
description: On this seven-song EP, the New York trio replaces the post-Nevermind feel of its debut with a purposefully regressive sound that brings to mind a mid-1980s Homestead Records signee.

title: All of Me
label: Atlantic
description: On her third record, Estelle's more focused on hitmaking than crafting a cohesive album statement.

title: Break It Yourself
label: Bella Union
description: Andrew Bird's latest album, which includes a duet with St. Vincent, finds the multi-instrumentalist working more collaboratively with a band than he has in a long time.

title: The Minimal Wave Tapes Vol. 2
label: Stones Throw
description: Compiled by Peanut Butter Wolf and Minimal Wave founder Veronica Vasicka, The Minimal Wave Tapes Vol. 2 offers a second gleaning of tracks from the cloistered minimal wave universe.

title: The Belbury Tales
label: Ghost Box
description: By welcoming in a couple of guest players on a number of tracks, the meticulous Welsh electronic musician Jim Jupp creates his most pleasingly open-ended release to date.

title: bell hooks
label: Mad Decent
description: On this DJ Benzi-hosted mixtape titled after the pen name of black feminist thinker Gloria Jean Watkins, the Chicago hip-hop crew throw a party without toning down their fiery rhetoric.

title: One Second of Love
label: Secretly Canadian
description: In the context of her catalogue, this feels like a coming out party for Ramona Gonzalez's Nite Jewel. Compared to the electro-pop project's more lo-fi beginnings, the music here is forthright and clear.

title: Open Your Heart
label: Sacred Bones
description: The Brooklyn quartet's excellent new LP treats the last four decades of rock music like an amusement park rather than a museum.

title: Killing Time
label: Slumberland
description: Featuring three members of Magic Bullets,the Troggs-inspired Bay Area trio balances an aggressive delivery and melodic, relatively reserved vocals on their debut LP.

title: Into the Waves
label: Drag City
description: The solo debut from Sophia Knapp, also a member of Cliffie Swan (formerly Lights), features a couple of duets with labelmate Bill Callahan.

title: Possession
label: Relapse
description: Frontwoman Christine Davis leads this Olympia metal quintet through no-frills proto-thrash, grandiose classic rock, and smoky doom on the band's sophomore LP.

title: Personality
label: Hotflush
description: Berlin-based UK producer Paul Rose eschews dubstep on his third Scuba LP, using prog house, trance, big beat, rave, old techno, and synth pop to create something stylishly retro.

title: Ekstasis
label: Rvng Intl.
description: On her second album, the California singer and songwriter pulls in references and sounds from everywhere and shapes them into music that's both haunting and life-affirming.

title: Silica Gel
label: self-released
description: James Ferraro drops much of the hip-hop inspired material of his last free mixtape on this follow-up released under his new Bodyguard moniker.

title: Pre Language
label: Kranky
description: The Chicago band's third LP features Sonic Youth's Steve Shelley as full-time drummer, and it's their most concise, commercial music to date.

title: Sounds From Nowheresville
label: Columbia
description: On the English duo's genre-hopping sophomore album the only common thread is how uniformly bad everything is.

title: Ghostory
label: Vagrant
description: Since their debut, School of Seven Bells have continuously pared down song length, sonic clutter, and personnel. On their third LP, the duo of Alejandra Deheza and Ben Curtis come across like they've achieved Zen perfection.

title: Sorrow and Extinction
label: Profound Lore
description: The debut album by this young doom metal outfit from Arkansas is startlingly well realized, with deep, sludgy guitar textures and proggy songs that are complemented by a sparkling melodic sensibility.

title: When You're Gone EP
label: Brainfeeder
description: UK producer Stuart Howard's Brainfeeder debut offers sparkling pop deconstructed with avant-garde abandon.

title: Beard, Wives, Denim
label: Modular
description: Sharing two members with Tame Impala, this Australian psych trio blends indulgent chunks of far-outness with fundamentally solid rock'n'roll tunes.

title: The Keychain Collection
label: Brownswood
description: On his debut, Will Ozanne combines the low-end physicality of bass music with the care and caution of cocktail-lounge fare.

title: Vee Vee (Remastered)
label: Merge
description: Seventeen years after its release, Archers of Loaf's sophomore album gets reissued as a 2xCD collection, remastered by original producer Bob Weston, and including 16 bonus tracks, liner notes, and new cover art.

title: How About I Be Me (And You Be You)?
label: One Little Indian
description: The title of Sinéad O'Connor's first album in five years might seem self-exploitive if it didn't so thoroughly comment on and confound her recent controversies. It's been ages since she's released a record this devastating.

title: The End of That
label: Secret City
description: On their third LP, the Montreal indie rock trio attempt to take unsparing inventory, offer sincere amends, and confront the responsibilities of adulthood.

title: TRST
label: Arts & Crafts
description: On their rich, room-filling debut, the Toronto electro-goth duo of Robert Alfons and Austra's Maya Postepski make malevolent, sexy synth-pop.

title: A Victim of Stars: 1982-2012
label: Virgin
description: This engaging compilation of work by the former Japan vocalist begins begins with a version of a song from his old band, moves through material from his solo LPs, and closes with a new song.

title: The Slideshow Effect
label: Sub Pop
description: The Ontario dream-pop duo's full-length debut is a painstaking portrayal of the dissolution of a relationship.

title: Toward the Low Sun
label: Drag City
description: After a seven-year absence, the Australian minimal violin/guitar/drum trio of Warren Ellis, Mick Turner, and Jim White unlearn everything they've known before in an attempt to start anew.

title: Modern Jester
label: Hanson
description: Six years after leaving Wolf Eyes, Aaron Dilloway releases a collection that feels like a major statement, even if it's made of wordless, sometimes harsh noise.

title: Splendor Squalor
label: Kanine
description: On their beefed-up sophomore collection, the Brooklyn new wave group, featuring members of Golden Triangle, picks one approach and runs with it.

title: Corrosion of Conformity
label: Candlelight
description: For their first album in seven years, the classic heavy-rock trio crafted the album they never got around to in their 20s, an LP recorded in Dave Grohl's studio that seethes with a swampy rawness they haven't embraced since the 1980s.

label: Delmore
description: Captured by a friend on a portable reel-to-reel, this 14-song collection finds the late folk singer in a cabin in Colorado, rehearsing for an upcoming show with her (soon-to-be-ex) husband.

title: Put Your Back N 2 It
label: Matador
description: Mike Hadreas' powerful second album addresses personal traumas like physical abuse, drug addiction, and desperation, but, unlike his 2010 debut Learning, some light shines through the darkness.

title: Hairdresser Blues
label: Hardly Art
description: The solo debut from the Hunx and His Punx frontman finds him reflecting on the past, writing ballads to his old friend Jay Reatard, his departed father, and the Bay City Rollers.

title: Underrated Silence
label: Bureau B
description: The German-born ambient artist collaborates with Mark Peters, his bandmate in the dream-pop band Engineers, on a collection of ethereal strum-and-woosh.

title: Audience of One
label: Touch
description: Across four pieces, including a cover of Ace Frehley's "Fractured Mirror", it feels like the Australian multi-instrumentalist is listening harder than ever to feel out new ways to move forward.

title: Recollected
label: Domino
description: Since 1990, the Leeds, England-based post-rock group Hood have created a blend of something modern and timeless. This six-disc set is not a full career overview, but a close focusing on their work for the Domino label.

title: Parastrophics
label: Monkeytown
description: After a six-year pause, Jan St. Werner and Andi Toma return with their best record since 2001's hyper-eclectic Idiology.

title: 808 Mafia
label: Brick Squad Monopoly
description: The joy of this instrumental mixtape by Lex Luger and fellow Atlanta producer Southside's crew is hearing the Luger sound done by originator-approved copycats.

title: Go Fly a Kite
label: The Noise Company
description: Ben Kweller's latest solo full-length, his first to be independently released, suggests that child prodigies might grow older faster than everybody else, too.

title: The Narrow Garden
label: Ipecac
description: The American composer and violinist's exploration of courtly love features an array of strings, winds, horns, and percussion, performed by an international cast of more than 30 musicians.

title: Dreams Say, View, Create, Shadow Leads
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Following 2010's Infinite Love, the onetime Ecstatic Sunshine and Ponytail guitarist offers a complex, well-crafted collection of loops and layers inspired, in part, by dreams.

title: The Something Rain
label: Constellation
description: On Tindersticks' ninth album, their best with their retooled lineup, the pop-noir balladeers strike the sweet spot between experimental sprawl and sultry soul.

title: Lilacs & Champagne
label: Mexican Summer
description: Grails' Alex Hall and Emil Amos have put together a gripping collection of sample-based, mostly-instrumental music: Think of the spookiest bits of small-press acid rock, library-music ephemera, and trans-continental exotica.

title: Blood for the Master
label: Metal Blade
description: The New Orleans death-metal quartet's fifth album is filled with songs about deicide, genocide, apocalypse, upheaval, bloodshed, and biting.

title: Maraqopa
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The Seattle singer/songwriter reunited with Saint Bartlett producer Richard Swift for his 10th studio album. The collection's success lies in the pair's restless experimentation.

title: Concerning the Entrance Into Eternity
label: Important
description: Jozef Van Wissem, the self-professed "lute player with a punk rock attitude," offers a collaborative LP with the film director (and guitarist) Jim Jarmusch.

title: Mr. M
label: Merge
description: Kurt Wagner and co.'s masterful 11th album is one of the best to emerge from their strange, modest universe.

title: Meltdown
label: Dirtnap
description: After a lo-fi debut he recorded largely by himself, Denton punk mainstay Mark Ryan (Marked Men, High Tension Wires) has assembled a mob of Texas garage staples to assist him with this robust followup.

title: Dub the World! Actually Remixed
label: Underwater Peoples
description: Wildly cosmopolitan Brooklyn trio La Big Vic's dub reinterpretation of its 2011 debut serves as a chance for the band to recontextualize itself without dulling its sonic expansiveness.

title: After Hours
label: Fool's Gold
description: Drawing on sample sources that rose in the wake of rave, the distinctive Huntsville, Alabama party-rap MC's mixtape with DJ Nick Catchdubs studiously avoids being simply a club record.

title: Generators
label: Editions Mego
description: Two versions of the Massachusetts electronic composer's 2009 piece "Generator", recorded live at separate shows in September 2010, form a terrifically fascinating contrast.

title: Interstellar
label: Slumberland
description: While kicking around the jangle-pop scene, Frankie Rose was a member of Vivian Girls, Crystal Stilts, and Dum Dum Girls. On her second solo album, she transports us further and takes us higher than she ever could have as the drummer of an indie pop revivalist band.

title: I Am Gemini
label: Saddle Creek
description: The latest convoluted concept album from Cursive is based on "twin brothers separated at birth" and "a classic struggle for the soul," but the real struggle is trying to make it all the way through.

title: Misery Wizard
label: Metal Blade
description: Guys with names like the Wizard, Krolg Splinterfest, Slayer of Man, and Count Elric the Soothsayer merge influences like Black Sabbath, Cathedral, and Sleep into a satisfying and distinctive whole.

title: In Ghostlike Fading
label: Warp
description: This Brooklyn band on Warp swirls together influences including the Verve, Spiritualized, and the Velvet Underground, aiming for a familiar kind of drug-sick state of grace.

title: Hive Mind
label: Planet Mu
description: On his debut Ital LP, Daniel Martin-McCormick (Mi Ami, Sex Worker, Black Eyes), jumbles familiar house signifiers until they represent something sloppy, shaggy, and surprisingly thoughtful.

title: Reign of Terror
label: Mom & Pop
description: Sleigh Bells' brash, hyperactive sophomore album is plenty loud. This time around, though, the duo emphasize the delicate elements of their sound in service of dynamic and ecstatic pop tunes.

title: Existers
label: Swill Children
description: The L.A.-based duo of Sarah Rara and Luke Fischbeck return to the techno-tribal primitivism of their earlier albums on this limited-edition collaboration with the visual artist Jesse Hlebo.

title: Better to Die on Your Feet Than Live on Your Knees
label: Relapse
description: This surprising grindcore record from Matthew Widener of Exhumed adds digitized horns, banjos, and martial drumming to the aggressive splatter, coming over like Napalm Death clobbering John Philip Sousa.

title: The Russian Wilds
label: American
description: Crafted over four years, the San Francisco psych-rock quintet's Rick Rubin-produced third album has all the tropes of a record-as-game-changer.

title: The Broken Man
label: Ici d'Ailleurs
description: The Bristol-born folk musician, who records electronic music as Third Eye Foundation, offers a robust, atmospheric set of songs enveloped in blood, sorrow, and torment.

title: Visions
label: 4AD
description: Grimes is the one-woman cyborg-pop project of Montreal's Claire Boucher. Visions, her compulsively listenable third album, is an electro cotton-candy entryway to her peculiar kind of bliss.

title: Living Room Songs / Another Happy Day OST
label: Erased Tapes
description: The Icelandic composer, known for releasing music in unusual ways, offers the straight-to-YouTube Living Room Songs and a score for Sam Levinson's film Another Happy Day.

title: Orcas
label: Morr
description: Electro-acoustic composers Thomas Meluch (aka Benoît Pioulard) and Rafael Anton Irisarri strike a balance between lyric-driven emotional appeals and aloof abstractions on this collection of nocturnal ambient pop.

title: The Hotel Sessions / Laughing All the Way to the Cleaners
label: Hall Of
description: The Hotel Sessions, a collection of demos recorded to a Walkman in 1992, and Laughing All the Way to the Cleaners, a conventional 2xCD collection of hits, offer different looks at some great songs Evan Dando wrote over the last 25 years.

title: Trap Back
label: 1017 Brick Squad
description: Like his best music, Gucci Mane's release with noted mixtape curator DJ Holiday is colorful, interesting, flagrantly dumb, and sneakily clever.

title: Animal Joy
label: Sub Pop
description: Jonathan Meiburg and co.'s latest album finds Shearwater dropping the arcane conceptual gambits of their recent "trilogy" and speaking in layman's terms emotionally and sonically.

title: Arrow
label: Partisan
description: The Erika Wennerstrom-fronted Cincinnati blues rock quartet (and Friday Night Lights favorites) strip things down on their crunchy Jim Eno-produced fourth album.

title: Les Voyages de l'Âme
label: Prophecy
description: The French metal veteran blends shoegaze sentimentality with black-metal aesthetics on his latest LP, the most accomplished Alcest offering yet.

title: Lixiviation
label: Finders Keepers
description: The work of classically trained electronic composer Suzanne Ciani effortlessly bridges the commercial and the avant garde. This compilation, spanning 1968-1985, is a perfect introduction to the far-reaching nature of her talents.

title: A Sleep & a Forgetting
label: Anti-
description: Spurred on by a bad breakup, Nick Thorburn showcases a renewed passion on this Rob Schnapf-mixed collection, the most cohesive Islands record to date.

title: Kindred EP
label: Hyperdub
description: A year after Street Halo, the London producer returns with another three-track EP, and this collection pretty much breaks every Burial precedent there is.

title: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sea Lions But Were Afraid to Ask
label: Slumberland
description: On their satisfying debut LP, this C86-nodding California noise-pop quintet mixes the familiar with the unexpected.

title: We Are the Works in Progress
label: Asa Wa Kuru
description: Featuring unreleased tracks from Deerhunter, Four Tet, and Terry Riley, among others, this compilation organized by Blonde Redhead's Kazu Makino benefits relief work in Japan for the 2011 meltdowns at the Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant.

title: White Flame
label: self-released
description: The latest entry in Lil B's Flame series-- mixtapes that can be all over the place, but often delve into the sounds and slang of classic New Orleans rap-- does not disappoint in its blend of the bizarre, fantastic, and unbelievably bad.

title: Biokinetics
label: Type
description: Biokinetics was the first album released on Berlin's Chain Reaction and 16 years later, Type has reissued Thomas Köner and Andy Mellwig's landmark experimental techno album.

title: Angels of Darkness, Demons of Light II
label: Southern Lord
description: The drone-metal syndicate, who reformed as an elegant blues band seven years ago, follow Angels of Darkness, Demons of Light 1 with an expansive, understated collection recorded during the same session as that 2011 album.

title: "Evidence" 12"
label: Mexican Summer
description: This EP for Ford & Lopatin's Software label finds Carlos Giffoni fusing the noise textures of his earlier experiments to acid house with intriguing results.

title: Plumb
label: Memphis Industries
description: Following their 2010 double album, Field Music's latest finds them returning to the more succinct and fractured impulses that guided their earlier work.

title: Given to the Wild
label: Fiction
description: Shifting gears from their first two records, the UK band's newest features production from Tim Goldsworthy and aims for a sound closer to Foals and Wild Beasts.

title: And Never Ending Nights
label: Magazine
description: Axel Willner of the Field slows down and crafts an ambient album under a new moniker that brings to mind the early masters of German electronic music.

title: Young and Old
label: Fat Possum
description: On their second LP, Tennis take the Brill Building tunefulness and classic indie-pop production values of their debut and add a bit of rock'n'roll muscle. Patrick Carney of Black Keys produces.

title: And They Turned Not When They Went
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The experimental outfit's latest is equal parts psych-folk songsmithery and musique concrète.

title: Hotel Amour
label: Kompakt
description: Drawing on some fiercely individual vocal collaborators, Paris-dwelling DJ/producer Fetisch and Berlin-based techno-oriented artist &ME's latest LP is caught somewhere between the current and the deep past.

title: Melt
label: Carpark
description: From their name on down, Young Magic seem very of-the-moment. Their debut album pulls together West African rhythms, twitchy beats, and the requisite layer of reverb.

title: Year of the Tiger
label: Matador
description: The newest installment in Fucked Up's series of songs for each year of the Chinese Zodiac is a pair of tracks that have been around for a while: a 15-minute song featuring Jim Jarmusch and a 22-minute instrumental paldindrome.

title: Ten$ion
label: ZEF
description: Not that anyone expected subtlety from Die Antwoord, but the South African trio's second studio album is id rap at its worst, lacking scope or imagination even in its excess.

title: Lineage
label: Ghostly
description: Zach Saginaw follows 2010's Full Circle with a mini-LP of homespun electronic music that traces his family bloodlines along with electronica's recent past.

title: Be the Void
label: Anti-
description: After recording their sixth record with Rob Schnapf, the Philadelphia rockers go it alone again on album seven, something of a return to the sunburnt sprawl of their first few LPs.

title: Subject: Matter
label: Stones Throw
description: Unapologetic about his intelligence, Angel Del Villar is the type of rapper beloved by hip-hop traditionalists: proudly old school, technically savage, and lyrically sharp. His debut EP for Stones Throw is his best work yet.

title: Six Cups of Rebel
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Hans-Peter Lindstrøm's second solo album moves away from his taut and sparse early work in favor of something more bombastic but strangely cloistered.

title: The Singles
label: Mute
description: Goldfrapp boils down their catalog to their 12 most successful singles and adds two new tracks, resulting in a tight set of their finest material sequenced like a dynamic, eclectic pop album.

title: Out of Sight, Out of Town
label: Melodic
description: On this Sheffield indie pop trio's charming sophomore album, Emma Kupa and co. have figured out how to braid together the different corners of their record collection.

title: After the Graveyard / Clear Skies Over Black River
label: Underwater Peoples
description: Liam Betson, occasional guitarist with Titus Andronicus, reissues two early home-recorded, self-distributed folk albums in anticipation of his first Liam the Younger studio LP.

title: The Oram Tapes, Vol. 1
label: Young American
description: Reinforcing the melancholy aspect of her work, this dark 44-track anthology of work by pioneering British electronic composer Daphne Oram draws from over 400 tapes she left behind after her death in 2003.

title: Live From the Kitchen
label: RCA
description: After a decade in the game, the Memphis rapper releases his first major-label album. Guests include Rick Ross, Big K.R.I.T., and 2 Chainz.

title: Le Voyage Dans la Lune
label: Astralwerks
description: Air's soundtrack to the restored version of Georges Méliès silent film Le Voyage Dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon) finds the duo trying to bring some artistry back into their music.

title: Feel the Sound
label: Merge
description: The longtime San Francisco quartet's fifth album showcases a care and craft usually lacking in indie pop's lesser lights.

title: Planet High School
label: Ghostly
description: The adventurous Brooklyn-via-Minneapolis DJ/producer Brian Lindgren streamlines the touchstones of his 2010 debut on his freewheeling sophomore LP.

title: The Black Session: Paris, 10 May 2011
label: Pinkflag
description: This fiery live recording, the first to feature Wire's most recent stage lineup, focuses on the elegantly textured 2011 collection Red Barked Tree.

title: Blues Funeral
label: 4AD
description: Citing albums by Kraftwerk, Joy Division, and Roxy Music as influences, the Gutter Twins/ex-Screaming Trees vocalist's first solo album since 2004 incorporates drum machines and oozing synths into the mix.

title: ƒIN
label: Permanent Vacation
description: In the past two years, John Talabot has become an exemplar of a new breed of producers working at the intersection of deep house, disco, and indie pop. On his debut, the Spanish producer builds upon his distinctive sound-- bursting with color, nostalgic but never retro, easy-going yet slightly unhinged-- without repeating himself.

title: Better Luck Next Life
label: Kanine
description: The Brooklyn-via-Bay Area garage duo's sludgy, gloomy second LP features songs about black souls, black hearts, S&M, and dark lords pounded out over Bo Diddley beats.

title: Man With Potential
label: Type
description: Pete Swanson has released a handful of cassette and LPs since his electronic noise duo Yellow Swans disbanded in 2008, but none have offered something this easy-- or oddly danceable-- to latch onto.

title: Keep it Together
label: Woodsist
description: On his ornate, pop-friendly fourth LP, enigmatic UK singer-songwriter the Doozer has abandoned his solo setup and recorded with close to a dozen other musicians.

title: Onwards to the Wall EP
label: Dead Oceans
description: The New York noise-rock band's followup to 2009's Exploding Head is a five-song EP that seems to aim for a greater appeal.

title: Paralytic Stalks
label: Polyvinyl
description: This is, without a doubt, Kevin Barnes' most fragmented record since the tail end of the project's Elephant 6 days.

title: The Horror
label: Sacred Bones
description: The N.Y. noise-punk quart's debut LP is an unabashedly grim collection, one that conjures the dystopian futurism of an early David Cronenberg film delivered with merciless brute force.

title: Clay Class
label: DFA
description: Five years after Prinzhorn Dance School's self-titled debut, the UK post-punk duo of Tobin Prinz and partner Suzi Horn remain defiantly un-evolved.

title: Ester
label: Domino
description: After surfacing three years ago with a fresh, powerful sound, the London dream-pop quartet release their debut LP.

title: Blondes
label: Rvng Intl.
description: The Brooklyn outsider house duo's debut LP collects three previously released 12"'s, a pair of new songs, and a second disc of remixes by Andy Stott, Teengirl Fantasy, and Laurel Halo, among others.

title: Instrumental University
label: Duke
description: Following on last year's hypnotic Electronic Dream, this set collects beats made for rappers including Lloyd Banks, Fabolous, Jim Jones, Cam'ron, Vado, and others.

title: They!Live
label: 50 Weapons
description: On paper, these bass-driven house producers seem like such a perfect match you'd expect any musical collaboration to mirror their work apart. It's surprising, then, how unlike their former selves They!Live turns out to be.

title: Tally Ho! Flying Nun's Greatest Bits
label: Flying Nun
description: The influential New Zealand label put together a 2xCD with songs from across its varied catalog to honor its 30th birthday.

title: No One Can Ever Know
label: Fat Cat
description: The Scottish trio's frigid, militant, rhythmic Andrew Weatherall-produced third LP is more about obsession than release.

title: We Will Always Be
label: Kranky
description: The Michigan-based husband and wife dream-pop duo's newest resembles an orderly dissection of the relationship cycle, making it feel as if the usual barriers between audience and performer simply aren't there.

title: iTunes Session
label: Anti-
description: This eight-song EP, comprised primarily of tracks from Wilco's most recent album The Whole Love, also finds them unearthing older song-oriented material that suggests they're getting back to the business of being a pop band.

title: Probably Love
label: M=Maximal
description: Stylized to abstraction, it is impossible to imagine Probably Love, o F F Love's debut LP, dropping any time but the present. One year ago it would've seemed obscure; one year from now, it will sound archaic.

title: Lock Out
label: self-released
description: Produced mostly by Southside and Lex Luger, the collaboration between Waka Flocka Flame and French Montana sounds more well-grounded in the streets of Atlanta than the East Coast rap scene.

title: I Love You
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Since the dissolution of his band Wzt Hearts, Jason Urick has made a series of records for Thrill Jockey that have moved through drone and dub-inflected atmosphere. This could be his best solo LP yet.

title: Rad Times Xpress IV
label: Drag City
description: Black Bananas boasts the same personnel as Jennifer Herrema's other post-Royal Trux band, but she fashions it as an alternate-universe RTX, one that isn't afraid to absorb modern influences like synth-pop, hip-hop, French-touch house.

title: Old Ideas
label: Columbia
description: Leonard Cohen's 12th studio LP is a spare, low-key album rooted in blues and gospel-- maybe the closest thing he's made to "folk" music since the early 1970s.

title: La Grande
label: Barsuk
description: The Oregon songstress spreads her wings and tries a few new styles on for size while keeping her earthly vision intact.

title: Earth Has Doors
label: Sacred Bones
description: The Fresh & Onlys lead guitarist has produced a dramatic, high-concept solo EP that taps into 1960s and 1970s prog bluster, complete with song titles long enough to require commas.

title: 936 Remixes 12" / 936 Remixed EP
label: Weird World
description: Following their excellent psych-pop breakthrough 936, Peaking Lights return with two very different remix EPs.

title: Anthology: 1992 to 2012
label: Cooking Vinyl
description: This 25-song "best of" compilation collects two decades of Underworld's widescreen progressive house at 12"-mix lengths, rather than the highlight reel-style radio edits.

title: Tramp
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter's powerful third album, produced by the National's Aaron Dessner, features guest spots from Beirut's Zach Condon, Wye Oak's Jenn Wasner, Julianna Barwick, and Dessner's brother Bryce, among others.

title: Astronaut Status
label: self-released
description: With a handful of hits, placements on albums by Young Jeezy and Rick Ross, and a major-label debut on the horizon, the Atlanta rapper's new mixtape is his first big move of the year.

title: Be Strong
label: DFA
description: This side project from Hot Chip's Joe Goddard and Raf Rundell make a goofy and big-hearted homage to the club-friendly pop they love.

title: Vacation EP
label: Friends of Friends
description: The L.A.-based beatmaker follow's last year's album, Bad Vibes, with a brief and beautiful three-song EP that shows an expanding mastery of sound manipulation.

title: Strange Weekend
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The Italian-born pop artist Mauro Remiddi has covered an impressive amount of physical and aesthetic terrain in his years as a working musician. On his bleary, atmospheric Porcelain Raft debut LP, he sounds like he no longer exists on this planet.

title: Born to Die
label: Interscope
description: After last year's hit "Video Games" and the endless remixes, leaks, think-pieces, and controversy that followed, it's finally here: the major-label debut from Lana Del Rey.

title: Feel Me EP
label: Dovecote
description: The Los Angeles multi-instrumentalist singer's latest EP drops as a short but grueling tour of cloying soul-without-soul.

title: U&I
label: Warp
description: Dumping the celebrity collaborators of 2008's Blood, Looms and Blooms, the London-based Iranian electronic musician's newest contains her most straightforward music to date.

title: To Solemn Ash
label: Exile On Mainstream
description: This young Danish sludge-metal trio has a familiar sound, but the band's ability to pen vast, melodic anthems is sharp enough that originality isn't really an issue.

title: Patience (After Sebald)
label: History Always Favours the Winners
description: Leyland Kirby follows last year's An Empty Bliss Beyond This World with the soundtrack to a film about German writer W.G. Sebald. Instead of jazz-age ballroom music, it samples and manipulates recordings of Franz Schubert's Winterreise.

title: Habits & Contradictions
label: Top Dawg
description: Schoolboy Q is the most promising foot soldier in Kendrick Lamar's Black Hippy crew, a small circle of talented rappers currently reinventing West Coast hip-hop. His dark and moody second LP is a sumptuously produced and deeply enjoyable hour-plus slab of weed-clouded rap, but it's more than that.

title: Sparrowmania: Wit, Wisdom and Soul From the King of Calypso 1962-1974
label: Strut
description: No singer has had a longer career in calypso and soca than Mighty Sparrow, and people deserve a two-disc Sparrow compilation to bury all other Sparrow compilations.

title: America Give Up
label: Rough Trade
description: These buzzed-about young Minnesotans offer spry and strummy rock music that leads to plenty of Strokes comparisons.

title: Hospitality
label: Merge
description: Piloted by multi-instrumentalist vocalist/songwriter Amber Papini, Brooklyn trio Hospitality's self-titled debut LP blends intelligent lyricism with shimmering, often surprising production.

title: Nehru Jackets / The Palm Wine Drinkard
label: Greedhead
description: Heems and Kool A.D. deliver two of three promised mixtapes from the Das Racist camp. While both lack the accessibility that marked the first two Das Racist tapes, they allow the rappers to indulge their most far-out ideas.

title: A Throne Without a King
label: Hydra Head
description: This spooky collaborative LP between avant-metal acts Pyramids and Horseback takes a real chance, risks real failure, and goes further out than either group has on its own.

title: Pop Ambient 2012
label: Kompakt
description: What does Kompakt's annual Pop Ambient series have left to say about the state of contemporary electronic music?

title: Wilson Semiconductors
label: Drag City
description: This ragged, four-song EP from the uncompromising Royal Trux songwriter/guitarist Neil Hagerty continues the drum-less setup of the Howling Hex's 2008 LP, Earth Junk.

title: File Under Sacred Music: Early Singles 1978-1981
label: Munster
description: Most of the songs that made the Cramps' reputation are collected on this suitably trashy box set of the band's early singles and other tracks from between 1978 and 1981.

title: Concealer EP
label: Vase
description: The inaugural release on the young Montreal producer Jacques Greene's new Vase imprint changes up the sample-based club formula he perfected on two excellent 2011 EPs.

title: MU.ZZ.LE
label: Warp
description: This 10-song EP scans like a means for the San Diego vocalist to transition into more personal territory. It's the rare album that feels meditative and cathartic all at once.

title: Amaranthine
label: MIE
description: You'd be hard-pressed to draw a direct line between Scottish avant-rock artist Richard Youngs' previous two albums and the haunted murk of this new limited-edition LP, even as it focuses on and amplifies many of his central obsessions.

title: The Lion's Roar
label: Wichita
description: The Swedish sisters Klara and Johanna Söderberg's sophomore album was recorded in Omaha with Bright Eyes' Mike Mogis and features guest spots from Conor Oberst and the Felice Brothers.

title: Resolution
label: Epic
description: The seventh album from one of America's few major-label metal acts feels like the unedited, overly long collection of a younger band trying to make its mark.

title: Furthur
label: self-released
description: The Toronto-based DropxLife was partly responsible for "Initiation", one of the highlights of the Weeknd's Echoes of Silence. He's collected a few of his own instrumental productions on this free-to-download mixtape.

title: Clear Heart Full Eyes
label: Vagrant
description: Dialing the music back and the intensity down, the Hold Steady frontman's first solo album feels like the culmination of the softened edges and blunted urgency of his band's more recent trajectory.

title: Hubble Drums
label: Northern Spy
description: The conservatory-trained jazz guitarist and sound engineer Ben Greenberg (Zs, the Men) channels his affinity for high intensity marathon guitar jams on this beautifully troubling Hubble debut.

title: Vodka & Ayahuasca
label: Decon
description: West Coast rap producers/MCs Alchemist and Oh No's most recent collaborative effort-- featuring guest spots from Kool G Rap and Roc Marciano, among others-- is a stab at drunk-psych nightmarishness that runs on slasher-flick suspense.

title: The Stars Are Indifferent to Astronomy
label: Barsuk
description: On their seventh album, Nada Surf set out to capture the raw, excited feel of a practice-room jam session.

title: DirteeTV.com
label: self-released
description: This free mixtape is designed as a showcase for Dizzee Rascal's label/crew Dirtee Stank, but it includes some of the most thrilling music the English rapper's recorded since his stomp-and-snarl days.

title: Attack on Memory
label: Carpark
description: Now a roaring, technically adept band rather than Dylan Baldi's bedroom solo project, Cloud Nothings undergo a total overhaul on their bracing Steve Albini-recorded second LP.

title: Back on Time
label: Ninja Tune
description: In the 1990s, the Cornish electronic musician Luke Vibert offered a pranksterish take on drum & bass under the Plug moniker. This collection of recordings from 1995-1998 foreshadows the kitchen-sink work of Rustie and James Ferraro.

title: Praktica
label: self-released
description: This nine-song mixtape finds the Pack's "Vans" producer coming close to matching the quality of his rapping to the quality of his producing. There's something undeniably kinetic about the cocky, self-assured artist honing his sound.

title: Unemployed
label: Rune Grammofon
description: The Norwegian electro-acoustic duo seems either incapable of or uninterested in repeating itself. On this album, they use location-based instrumental recordings, found sound, and field recordings, mixing it with studio work that blends samples and live instruments.

title: SXLND EP
label: LuckyMe
description: One half of the bass duo Sepalcure issues a five-song collection under his longtime Machinedrum moniker, including a title track that served as the backbone for Azealia Banks' latest single.

title: Something
label: Columbia
description: Chairlift's second full-length album is a major creative leap from their first, but it doesn't so much reinvent their sound as refine it.

title: Dimensional Rip 7: Thee Physical Remixes
label: self-released
description: Pictureplane mastermind Travis Egedy's free download series has played host to a handful of jumbled, messy mixes. The seventh installment contains remixes of tracks of his 2011 LP, Thee Physical, featuring tweaks by Grimes, Physical Therapy, and others.

title: Freermasonry
label: Profound Lore
description: With a lyrical conceit based on Masonic symbolism and Biblical scripture, the obliterative sixth album from Saskatchewan's Wold is an enigmatic intersection of noise, metal, and electronics.

title: Kinks in Mono
label: Sanctuary
description: This 10xCD boxset collects the entirety of the Kinks' 1960s output, in mono as the title implies. It's a well-designed package created with a lot of love, and the music is as brilliant as it ever was, but is that enough?

title: Fallen Empires
label: Polydor
description: Snow Patrol have called this new album a showcase for their "secret love of techno." The collection does feature electronics, along with arrangements from Owen Pallett and Nico Muhly and a heavy dose of female gospel vocals.

title: Headcage EP
label: Ghostly
description: This laid-back four song EP both picks up where Matthew Dear's last record left off and shakes its influence enough to suggest where he might be headed next.

title: Dark Matters
label: Group Tightener
description: On this debut LP, the young New York City native Alec Feld-- whose voice wouldn't sound out of place on a Wolf Parade or Animal Collective anthem-- creates synth music with a sleepy grandeur.

title: Iron Balls of Steel
label: Southern Lord
description: Over the course of a decade, the highly regarded ultra-technical instrumental-metal outfit Loincloth's discography totaled four songs. The N.C.-Va. trio's debut LP leaves room for a broader audience to hear what the fuss was all about.

title: Friend of the People
label: self-released
description: Lupe Fiasco's new mixtape samples Justice and M83 and shows a strong interest in aggressively macho dubstep. For about a third of it, you feel actively punished for paying attention.

title: CYRK
label: Control Group
description: The cool, disaffected Welsh avant-pop chanteuse's second album is more playful and irreverent than her debut, a 2009 collection released by collaborator/mentor Gruff Rhys of Super Furry Animals.

title: Voyageur
label: Zoe
description: Kathleen Edwards co-produced her fourth album with Justin Vernon of Bon Iver, jettisoning country rock in favor of gauzy production and a band that includes Vernon plus members of Megafaun, Francis & the Lights, and Peter Wolf Crier.

title: Blue Dream & Lean
label: self-released
description: One half of Memphis' legendary Three 6 Mafia offers a continuation of his two collaborative mixtapes with Lex Luger, a druggy 28-track album featuring guest spots from A$AP Rocky, Spaceghostpurpp, and Kreayshawn, among others.

title: Hymns
label: Fire
description: In 1994, Eric Matthews and Richard Davies released an influential chamber-pop album under the name Cardinal. Almost 20 years later, they've reunited for its follow-up.

title: Evolve or Be Extinct
label: Big Dada
description: It's arguable that even Wiley can't remember every track he's released in the past half-decade, but the grime godfather's new LP is one you should play closer attention to.

title: Fuck Da City Up
label: self-released
description: Fresh from his most recent dalliance with hard time, this mixtape-- featuring guest spots from Young Jeezy, Nelly, Dr. Dre, and others-- finds T.I. back in the scrappy mode of his early days.

title: The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo OST
label: The Null Corporation
description: Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross follow their award-winning score to David Fincher's The Social Network with this bleak three-hour The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo soundtrack, a sprawling mass that exceeds the length of the film it was meant for.

title: Morning & Sunrise
label: De Stijl
description: The Swedish psych-folkie and beet farmer follows his brilliant 2005 debut Moonlight Farm with a more electric, more rock-inclined offering that finds him returning to the earlier record's evocative terrain without repeating himself.

title: Natural Traits
label: Friends of Friends
description: The San Antonio producer, who records cinematic sorta-dance music as Mexicans With Guns, offers post-rock for the Flying Lotus generation on this new solo LP.

title: It's the Arps
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: The Norwegian space disco producer follows last year's surprisingly sticky Ragysh EP with a refreshingly clean four-track EP composed with an ARP2600 analog synthesizer.

title: Unexpected Victory
label: self-released
description: Armed with passable productions and an uneven roster of guest stars, the Wu-Tang dynamo's first full-length release since 2011's Shaolin vs. Wu-Tang LP rarely smacks of anything like victory. The sound's too lousy-- and the stakes too low-- to live up to his past glories.

title: Future This
label: 4AD
description: After the explosive and decadent A Brief History of Love, the Big Pink return with an album that aims for positivity and a deeper connection with their audience.

title: Five Years With the Sun EP
label: JUKBOXR
description: In the hushed tones of this brief collection, the young Fort Lauderdale electronic songwriter Malcom Lacey dramatizes the process of a gentle person grappling with dark thoughts.

title: Fabriclive 61
label: Fabric
description: Dubstep pioneer Rob Ellis' exciting entry in the Fabriclive series occupies a many-limbed vaguely house, vaguely techno hinterland: It's damaged, blackened, and foreboding, no matter what genre it might be interrogating.

title: Inhale C-4 $$$$$
label: self-released
description: Following the success of last year's polarizing Far Side Virtual, James Ferraro puts out a free, victory lap mixtape, one that finds him developing a mutant strain of mainstream rap and R&B.

title: Journey of the Deep Sea Dweller I
label: Clone
description: From 1992 until 2002, the mysterious electro outfit Drexciya created not only some of Detroit's most original, enduring electronic music, but one of techno's greatest myth systems. This compilation-- the first in a planned four-volume anthology-- serves as a crucial introduction.

title: Rich Forever
label: Unknown
description: Rick Ross' new mixtape, possibly his best full-length, finds the Teflon Don moving out of his comfort zone and entering a world where it feels like something is at stake.

title: Rush Hour Presents Amsterdam All Stars
label: Rush Hour
description: This set of 12 exclusive tracks, which offers a portrait of the current house music talent operating in or originating from Amsterdam, is filled with raucous, 4/4 shakers born in the 1980s in Chicago but possessing updated wardrobes.

title: Live at Artists Space
label: Feeding Tube
description: Feeding Tube teams with Mars bassist Mark Cunningham to offer the entirety of his no wave band's two-set performance from the 1978 Artists Space festival, the same event that led Brian Eno to compile his scene-defining compilation No New York.

title: Slime Flu 2
label: self-released
description: The goofy Harlem rapper and Cam'ron sidekick's new mixtape delivers what the original Slime Flu did-- high-speed, tightly realized, pugilistic goon rap-- to nearly as entertaining results.

title: OvalDNA
label: Shitkatapult
description: This remarkably consistent, 25-track collection of bits and bytes from assorted past Oval eras flies by in an easygoing blur, rendering sounds in a fluid and volatile technicolor that's missing from even the project's classic records.

title: Alone III: The Pinkerton Years
label: Geffen
description: Unlike the previous Alone iterations, Alone III: The Pinkerton Years feels like an actual Weezer album rather than Rivers Cuomo's yard sale. It's a bracing, imperfect reminder of a time when music was something Cuomo couldn't live without.

title: Black Cocaine EP
label: Infamous
description: On Havoc and Prodigy's first recording since the latter's release from prison, Mobb Deep sound unsure where they stand, too proud to change their style and too much of a name brand to bother.

title: Escort
label: Escort
description: The New York live disco ensemble's self-titled debut is not just the pinnacle of 21st-century disco fetishism, it's a great pop record, even if it's working off 1979's pop template rather than 2011's.

title: Shadows EP
label: Eglo
description: This elegant 2x12"-- Sam Shepherd's longest, most cohesive release to date-- suggests the London producer, DJ, and composer is continuing to filter his approach to rhythm and melody.

title: Henge Beat
label: Iron Lung
description: Featuring Mikey Young of Eddy Current Suppression Ring, among others, Total Control is as close to a supergroup as a tandem of cult Australian punks can get. Surprisingly, their debut LP surpasses even the top-shelf efforts from their other bands.

title: Live at the Paramount
label: Geffen
description: One month after Nirvana released Nevermind, they performed at Seattle's Paramount Theatre on Halloween. The joy of Live at the Paramount is hearing the charge of this moment: a great band newly famous, still reeling and flooded with nervy adrenaline.

title: Vienna Blue
label: self-released
description: Johannes Auvinen's final offering of 2011 is an icy free-of-charge chamber pop record unlike anything the Vienna-based techno auteur has previously released.

title: Items
label: Dull Knife
description: The minimalist Brooklyn post-punk trio's debut-- one showcasing savvy terseness and catchy, simple songs-- is an ode to domestic boredom and romantic dissatisfaction.

title: Bobby Charles
label: Rhino Handmade
description: Reissued here as a wood-paneled box set with 25 bonus tracks, Louisiana singer Robert Charles' lone album from the 1970s, featuring four members of the Band as his backup group, is one of the most sublime Americana records ever cut.

title: Elemental Parts 1 & 2
label: Modern Love
description: On this 4xLP set-- soon to be reissued as a 2xCD-- the British duo continue spelunking through a dank netherworld. More focused than 2010's Tryptych, Elemental conveys a sense of mystery that goes beyond affect.

title: The Dreamer/The Believer
label: Warner Bros.
description: Common bounces back from the low point of his career with his best album since 2005's Be. Produced by soul-rap veteran No I.D. and featuring Nas, Maya Angelou, and John Legend, The Dreamer/The Believer has moments that recall the humanity and thoughtfulness of his mid-90s classics.

title: Glimmer
label: Ghostly
description: Think of the new album by Polish electroacoustic producer Michał Jacaszek as a symphony, just with singles, and made by a musician who can't decide between the roles of producer or composer.

title: Black Flute
label: Greedhead
description: The Brooklyn band's debut LP, released on Das Racist's Greedhead label, finds the trio doing away with the wavy, reverb-soaked production of 2010's Baby Style EP, forefronting lyrics that are inscrutable conflations of philosophy, sex, and religion.

title: Free Again: The "1970" Sessions
label: Omnivore
description: In 1970, after the Box Tops and before forming Big Star, Alex Chilton holed up in a Memphis studio and recorded an album's worth of material. Omnivore Records has now reissued those sessions, long out of print, with bonus tracks.

title: Boss of All Bosses 3
label: Diplomat
description: Despite the misleading title, Cam'ron and Vado's latest mixtape is actually the fifth in their Boss of All Bosses series. "Diminishing returns" is putting it lightly.

title: Box Set
label: Neutral Milk Hotel
description: This lavish vinyl-only box set collects the two proper Neutral Milk Hotel albums along with two 10" EPs and three 7"s. Taken together, it's a rewarding, carefully constructed tribute to Jeff Mangum's distinctive songwriting voice.

title: Spills Out
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The sprawling third album from the Brooklyn post-punks bristles with basement-show energy one minute, haunting Zombies-style harmonies the next. For the most part, Spills Out manages to revel in its own clutter.

title: Jet World Order
label: Jets International
