description: The wonderful Arrangements, Vol. 1 draws on Parks' self-described "earliest studio adventures," featuring a dizzying cast of collaborators (Little Feat, Arlo Guthrie, Bonnie Raitt singing calypso) with his unifying hand presiding over the collision of styles.

title: An Argument With Myself
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The Swedish indie-pop dramatist's new EP is a compact gem, one that shows different facets of the singer. Each song does something distinct both sonically and lyrically, filtering one rarified but relatable sensibility through guise after revealing guise.

title: Again Into Eyes
label: Mute
description: The so-called "little Horrors" feature Horrors' Rhys Webb's little brother on bass and share similarites with their elders on the musical and haircuts-and-cheekbones levels, but their debut suggests the Valerie Solanas-referencing post-punk group is capable of outgrowing some of these associations.

title: Zig Zaj
label: Lex
description: Bryan Hollon's first Boom Bip full-length since 2005 features Franz Ferdinand's Alex Kapranos, Money Mark, Empire of the Sun's Luke Steele, the Red Hot Chili Peppers' Josh Klinghoffer, and some unwise decisions.

title: Red EP
label: Slumberland
description: Offered as a teaser for the dark San Francisco noise-pop trio's as-yet-untitled, upcoming sophomore album, this five-song EP finds the band operating in a cleaner, dreamier mode.

title: Mikal Cronin
label: Trouble in Mind
description: On his solo debut, the California garage-rock multi-instrumentalist and Ty Segall collaborator concocts a collection of wistful, psychedelic pop that pits lush and layered arrangements against needle-pinning power chords. Like Segall, Cronin brings a young energy to classic rock sounds.

title: Fabriclive 59
label: Fabric
description: Kieran Hebden's conceptually tight Fabriclive 59 mix is built upon the restless UK garage scene, which from the late 1990s to the early 2000s mutated from a simultaneously roughed-up and opulent take on house music to the fierce and rap-derived clang-and-bang of grime.

title: Visits
label: Suicide Squeeze
description: After five years and two EPs, this onetime-improvisational outfit's debut LP features structured and sturdy rock music driven by an on-the-fly soul. Like Spacemen 3 with Wembley Stadium aspirations.

title: American Goldwing
label: Sub Pop
description: The Portland band's sixth album is named for a touring motorcycle meant for long hauls down endless highways, but a decade into their career, Blitzen Trapper sound less like denizens of the road and more like tourists snapping pictures of rock-historical monuments.

title: The Devil's Walk
label: Mute
description: The thoughtful German electronic musician's first album in four years arrives at a time when vocal electronic music is more popular than ever, but his melancholic, yearning phrasing occasionally pushes things closer to Coldplay than to James Blake.

title: Pop Music / False B-Sides
label: Anticon
description: This collection of post-Cerulean material-- previously available only as a limited tour CD-- is Will Wiesenfeld's latest attempt to crush the competing sides of his personality into song.

title: The 5 EPs
label: One Little Indian
description: In the early and mid 1990s, the British trio Disco Inferno wrote two albums and five EPs that comprised some of the most forward-thinking rock of the era. The Five EPs is a record that should be heard by anyone with an interest in those rare times when rock attempts brashly to chart new sonic territory.

title: Soita Mulle
label: Friendly Fire
description: On their fourth album, the Finnish indie pop trio offers a clean take on shoegaze highlighted by frontwoman Iisa Pykäri's improved vocals. Unfortunately, they still succumb to outside-the-lines genre explorations that don't always work.

title: Haven
label: Green Owl
description: Best known for his cavernous, doom-drunk remix of the xx's "Islands", Copenhagen-via-California musician Steven Borth's debut LP is something of a dubstep primer for the uninitiated. If you're feeling generous.

title: Veronica Falls
label: Slumberland
description: On its Slumberland debut, the London boy/girl indie-pop quartet churns out expertly stagy revivalism with the slightest hint of mutiny, creating shoegaze that looks you square in the eye.

title: Megafaun
label: Hometapes
description: The shapeshifting North Carolinian folk-rock trio's new self-titled LP dials back on the clawhammer outbursts and out-from-nowhere harmonic blasts that peppered the band's earlier work, but still offers plenty of surprises.

title: Life Sux EP
label: Ghost Ramp
description: Nathan Williams treats his Ghost Ramp label's inaugural release, an EP featuring guest spots from Best Coast's Bethany Cosentino and Fucked Up's Damian Abraham, like a 24-year old's first apartment: Maybe you'd only want to spend 15 minutes in this ramshackle mess, but hey, he's enjoying his freedom.

title: Some Easy Magic
label: HoZac
description: No one in this restrained-beyond-their-ages Texas garage-rock trio's old enough to legally buy cigarettes, but you get the feeling they are well beyond their years. Their sophomore collection offers a complete stylistic overhaul.

title: Paradise
label: Moshi Moshi
description: The Sheffield duo's sophomore album dials down its predecessor's twee, hyper-romantic delight in favor of songs that emphasize rhythm and atmosphere, with lyrics confronting more emotionally complicated subject matter. But that's not the most drastic shift.

title: It Can Be Done, But Only I Can Do It
label: FXHE
description: On Omar S's second self-released album-- the rare techno/house album that feels inimitably of its own time-- the Detroit native remains refreshingly uninterested in the unspoken pissing contest that is every producer's attempt to make the "deepest" record in any given DJ crate.

title: Portamento
label: Frenchkiss
description: Despite the well-fed egos, Jonathan Pierce and co.'s new album-- one that features ugly, petty, real emotion and multiple references to death or dying-- is a smaller, more intimate record than last year's self-titled predecessor.

title: Relax
label: Greedhead
description: On their first commercially released album, Das Racist sound unimpressed by their own staggering ability, as if the actual process of making Relax didn't turn out to be as exciting as planning it.

title: Chartreuse Bull
label: Sleeping Giant Glossolalia
description: Now a trio, the Hammerhead-associated New York noise-rockers release their first album in five years, just in time for the "pigfuck" renaissance.

title: Blueprint: The Best of 808 State
label: Salvo
description: This career-spanning "greatest bits" collection proves that-- without writing pop songs-- the ambitous 1990s British crossover dance act had a commercial instinct almost form the start, often scoring with the material that sounded the least sellable.

title: Feast or Famine EP
label: SWTBRDS
description: The thoughtful Bay Area rapper follows his solid debut with an EP that refines his existing style, relying on a distinctively wistful production aesthetic and the kind of rapping that feels like a labor of love, from an artist who sees hip-hop as a career.

title: Hysterical
label: self-released
description: After a five-year hiatus that's been described as something of a fact-finding mission for their true identity, Alec Ounsworth and co.'s third album casts them as the very thing their detractors claimed them to be so long ago.

title: Era Extraña
label: Mom & Pop
description: Forgoing the scrappy charm of Psychic Chasms, Alan Palomo's sophomore album-- recorded mostly alone in Finland in the dead of winter-- chronicles the Texas-raised musician's solitary longing and heartsickness with a commitment to tighter, wide-reaching songcraft.

title: Psychic Welfare
label: Rvng Intl.
description: On their third stuido album, Philadelphia's Pink Skull add more members and more songs with vocals, but skimp on the Led Zeppelin jokes.

title: A Winged Victory for the Sullen
artist: A Winged Victory for the Sullen
label: Kranky
description: Stars of the Lid's Adam Wiltzie and pianist/composer Dustin O'Halloran find a halfway point between their projects, creating music that moves more than drone and feels thicker than minimalism.

title: Gravity the Seducer
label: Nettwerk
description: For the Liverpool mainstays' fifth album, they've removed the cinder block that Velocifero applied to the gas pedal, opting for a floatier, airy feel that often sounds as if its creators' feet are barely touching the ground.

title: Verde Terrace
label: Datpiff.com
description: What often gets shortchanged in Curren$y’s "weed rapper" label is the compelling slipperiness of his mind. This DJ Drama mixtape finds the MC, like onetime mentor Lil Wayne, continuing to refine the contours of his tiny universe so that it resembles no one else's.

title: Wild Flag
label: Merge
description: The Sleater-Kinney/Helium/Minders supergroup's self-titled debut invokes first-wave punk, post-hardcore indie rock, and other styles, but Wild Flag aren't so much trying to relive a particular era or movement as re-stoke the kind of passion, commitment, and fandom in listeners that allowed those movements to coalesce and flourish in the first place.

title: A Creature I Don't Know
label: Ribbon Music
description: On her third album, the British singer-songwriter proves to be an artist deeply invested in archetypes, one who doesn't muck about with the details of 21st-century life in her explorations of desire, loss, and understanding.

title: Dreams Come True
label: Warp
description: Grizzly Bear member, Twin Shadow producer, and Terrible Records honcho Chris Taylor releases his first solo venture, a mission statement for his glossy, stylish in-house sound.

title: Eleven Fingers
label: Handmade Birds
description: For a few years now, this Finnish duo has been finding ways to merge its love of Joy Division and corpse paint into a dark and depressive sort of blackened post-punk, and this is arguably its strongest and most concise record.

title: Earth Division EP
label: Sub Pop
description: This soft, melancholic, four-song EP finds the Scottish post-rockers in soundtrack mode, and it ranks among Mogwai's least fiery, least riotous recordings.

title: Strange Mercy
label: 4AD
description: On Strange Mercy, Annie Clark ditches Marry Me's naivety and Actor's ostentatious arrangements, boosts the inventive guitar playing, and ends up with her most potent and cathartic release yet.

title: Mountaintops
label: Barsuk
description: After the misstep of 2008's Re-Arrange Us, the husband-and-wife duo Jason Hammel and Kori Gardner return to form, while offering the first of their records to grapple with the everyday tribulations and banality of spending your entire adult life in a band.

title: Odyshape
label: We ThRee
description: Despite living in an era when almost all music is available on tap, the Raincoats' 1981 post-punk classic still feels like a self-contained secret. It's telling that Sonic Youth's Kim Gordon was brought in to provide sleeve notes but doesn't say a single word about the record, and no demos, outtakes, or other ephemera are included.

title: Tripper
label: Sargent House
description: After revamping into a five-piece supergroup for 2007's There's No 666 in Outer Space, Hella's back to their original two-piece incarnation and business as usual.

title: Freaking Out EP
label: Carpark
description: After switching things up with this year's ambitious LP Underneath the Pine, Chaz Bundick  turns toward sweetly catchy and more explicitly funky 80s-tinged dancefloor jams.

title: Father, Son, Holy Ghost
label: True Panther
description: Girls' second LP is an album rich with feeling and alive with color and personality. The first listen brings with it an almost eerie sense of familiarity, like these are songs you've been hearing your whole life even when you can't place them, all the while managing to sound like no one else.

title: Making Mirrors
label: Samples 'n' Seconds
description: Here Australia singer-songwriter Walter De Backer finds room for psych-rock, soul, earnest balladeering, creepy retro-futurism, electronic and Tropicalia touches, and scads of serious-minded 1980s-inspired art pop.

title: Whatever Brains
label: Sorry State
description: Moving beyond their shaggy, lo-fi singles, the Minutemen-referencing, Pavement-nodding North Carolina band's eponymous full-length finds the band continuing to practice an all-inclusive musical channel-surfing.

title: WTC 9/11
label: Nonesuch
description: Steve Reich's memorial to September 11, which takes a form similar to 1989's Different Trains, another project he committed to tape with Kronos Quartet, mixes music with emergency dispatches from 9/11 and interviews conducted in 2010 with his close friends.

title: Who's Afraid of the Art of Noise [Deluxe Edition]
label: Salvo
description: Paired with original and alternate videos and BBC radio sessions, the London avant-garde pop conceptualists' 1984 debut is as sly, stirring, and occasionally infuriating now as it was on release.

title: Re: ECM
label: ECM
description: Techno producer Ricardo Villalobos and longtime experimentalist Max Loderbauer were given full access to Munich jazz/out label ECM's vast catalog. The resulting two-disc, two-hour offering is not a remix collection, but rather a rich, complex suite of compositions that converse with ECM's history.

title: La Liberación
label: V2
description: After a downer of a sophomore album, the Brazilian group's third record finds the band torn between pandering to the hopped-up hedonists who want to rip off Lovefoxxx’s clothes when she does a stage dive and a desire to dial down the crassness and redefine their character.

title: 808s & Dark Grapes II
label: Unknown
description: The young Oakland, California, DIY lo-fi rap duo couldn't have come along at a better time, but their fourth freebie mixtape released in the past year offers an endearing voice where others simply troll.

title: Red Sugar
label: Sub Rosa
description: With a style that sometimes recalls the gothic drone of Nico's The Marble Index, the Brooklyn-based French/Israeli duo's second album-- focused on the politics, religion, power struggles, and prejudice that bring people into conflict-- is "heavy" in every sense of the word, but they have a way of leavening the nightmare with glimmers of beauty.

title: Atma
label: Profound Lore
description: The Oregon doom metal trio's newest, an expansive album that never takes the space it's been given for granted, is a reminder that, in this crowded field, there are simply those who do it better.

label: Radio Killa
description: The-Dream self-released this intensely personal fourth solo collection for free. It's out under his birth name and titled for his birth year, and though he's been coy about the subject, the specter of his divorce from singer Christina Milian looms over it.

title: Garden of Arms
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The new-look Minneapolis folk duo's highly dramatic sophomore album features a welcome dose of confidence along with a sense of experimentation that doesn't always come off.

title: Geidi Primes
label: No Pain in Pop
description: Claire Boucher's cassette-only debut of "post-Internet" DIY bedroom recordings gets an old-fashioned CD/LP release. Following a wave of hype, the re-release is a wisely timed holdover for the months before her next album comes out, but the immersive, enchanting collection is more than a quaint indicator of how far Grimes has come in the past year and a half.

title: The Years EP
label: Sub Pop
description: After signing to Sub Pop, the Toronto dream pop duo re-records and re-works its debut EP, raising the question: Why go back and fix something that wasn't broken?

title: Lenses Alien
label: Barsuk
description: The Staten Island quartet follows Why There Are Mountains, its self-released debut of 1990s indie rock alchemy, with a difficult and potentially divisive sophomore LP, a lyrics-first record that puts confidence in the listener's attention span.

title: Looping State of Mind
label: Kompakt
description: The music on the Field's third album may be still be built from loops, but Axel Willner has never orchestrated so many of them so artfully. His dense and infinitely listenable soundscapes put his acolytes to shame.

title: Work (work, work)
label: Ghostly
description: After the suicide of bassist Sean Stewart last year, the no wave-leaning art noise duo pushes forward with its second full-length. Here they sport a noticeably minimal sound, with dark groaning and clanking that draws from coldwave and a host of other creepy signifiers.

title: Anthology
label: 4AD
description: On the 25th anniversary of their debut, Throwing Muses release the 2xCD retrospective Anthology. It's more a mixtape compiled by the band than an exhaustive box set or greatest-hits collection, but it's still an accessible entry point to the band’s formidably deep catalogue.

title: Violent Hearts
label: Hardly Art
description: This trio from British Columbia has a way of running music from the distant past through a noisy filter that owes something to Deerhunter; if they never quite reach that band's level of  euphoria, they're still off to a good start.

title: Ruin
label: Acéphale
description: As this compilation of the previously issued RUIN 1 and RUIN 2 EPs illustrates, the music of the Whitehouse-referencing Minneapolis production duo of James Brooks and Josh Clancy is proudly unaffiliated, cobbling together influences from jungle to hip-hop to noise to shoegaze.

title: In the Grace of Your Love
label: DFA
description: The galvanizing New York dance-punk trio returns with a long-anticipated third album that sounds like the Rapture without retreading past successes. It's a nifty trick that underscores the band's hard-won identity and it happens to come at a time when house and disco are more fashionable than any period since the early 1980s.

title: Glazin'
label: Hardly Art
description: The second album from these Florida up-and-comers features carefully crafted, smartly executed, and reasonably lively garage-rock that finds them sounding comparatively settled since their last LP, 2009's No Seasons.

title: Forget
label: Fat Possum
description: Following his other group's debut album from earlier this year, Yuck bandleader Daniel Blumberg strikes a different pose with Oupa, planting mostly solo piano songs in an orb of bare, sensitive melancholy.

title: Young People's Church of the Air
label: Sockets
description: The Washington D.C./Brooklyn quartet's sophomore album stakes out a unique ground between pop and experimental impulses, and deep down beneath the digital grot, it strikes an undeniably redemptive tone.

title: Azari & III
label: Loose Lips
description: On their full-length debut, these playful house producers solidify themselves as an album act. Here, they take clear references to specific musical eras and tie them together with a distinctive production aesthetic and strong personality.

title: The Golden Age of Apocalypse
label: Brainfeeder
description: Stephen "Thundercat" Bruner's densely layered debut (co-produced with Flying Lotus) mixes the future shock of electronics, the tightly edited pleasures of pop, the love-sick opulence of quiet-storm soul, and the show-stopper instrumental breaks of jazz

title: Simulat
label: 50 Weapons
description: The Berlin-based electronic producer's constant shapeshifting has made it difficult to identify him with a scene or sound. At its best, his debut full-length offers techno's dystopic vistas with an off-center hint of warmth.

title: Young People's Church of the Air
label: Sockets
description: The Washington D.C./Brooklyn quartet's sophomore album stakes out a unique ground between pop and experimental impulses, and deep down beneath the digital grot, it strikes an undeniably redemptive tone.

title: Azari & III
label: Loose Lips
description: On their full-length debut, these playful house producers solidify themselves as an album act. Here, they take clear references to specific musical eras and tie them together with a distinctive production aesthetic and strong personality.

title: The Golden Age of Apocalypse
label: Brainfeeder
description: Stephen "Thundercat" Bruner's densely layered debut (co-produced with Flying Lotus) mixes the future shock of electronics, the tightly edited pleasures of pop, the love-sick opulence of quiet-storm soul, and the show-stopper instrumental breaks of jazz

title: Simulat
label: 50 Weapons
description: The Berlin-based electronic producer's constant shapeshifting has made it difficult to identify him with a scene or sound. At its best, his debut full-length offers techno's dystopic vistas with an off-center hint of warmth.

title: Luminaries & Synastry
label: Digitalis
description: Prolific drone-maker Rachel Evans, aka Motion Sickness of Time Travel, has a knack for shaping subtle rhythms, slow crescendos, and the wordless phrasings of her own voice. That voice is more prominent than ever on her best solo outing to date.

title: The World Is Just a Shape to Fill the Night
label: Sacred Bones
description: The Dutchess and the Duke's Jesse Lortz strikes out on his own with an unremittingly bleak folk album that calls to mind Bill Callahan and the Tallest Man on Earth.

title: I'm With You
label: Warner Bros.
description: I'm With You, the first Red Hot Chili Peppers album without John Frusciante since the turgid, Dave Navarro-helmed One Hot Minute, is the work of a band with all kinds of capital to blow but no incentive to do anything differently.

title: Obscurities
label: Merge
description: Though it's a collection of odds, ends, side projects, and B-sides from the pre-69 Love Songs era, Obscurities is surprisingly coherent and also a good reminder of the strength of Stephin Merritt's early songwriting and his ability to get the most out of his rotating cast of vocalists.

title: Ancient Romans
label: Drag City
description: Cameron Stallones' latest LP under the Sun Araw name is another fever dream of dub-mottled organ grind and guitar squiggle; at once elemental and futuristic, it's less a departure from than a refinement of his 2010 breakout On Patrol.

title: Ghost on the Canvas
label: Surfdog
description: Recently diagnosed with Alzheimer's, this living legend of pop crafts a final, surprisingly upbeat retirement album, one that never stoops to self-pity and very modestly reminds you of past triumphs. The set includes new songs by Paul Westerberg and Robert Pollard and guest spots from Billy Corgan, the Dandy Warhols, and more.

title: Fever Dream
label: Anticon
description: On Fever Dream, the adventurous anticon. label's lowest-profile founding member aims to disrupt his comfortable patterns as a producer.

title: Last King 2: God's Machine
label: self-released
description: In between this spring's still-resonant mixtape Return of 4eva and his forthcoming Def Jam debut Live From the Underground arrives this mixed grab bag of Big K.R.I.T.'s various guest spots from over the last year.

title: The Sophtware Slump
label: V2
description: Grandaddy's sad, quaint, low-key Y2K-era classic, which captured the point where the deflated myth of the American West met the deflated myth of technological salvation, gets the deluxe reissue treatment.

title: Quadruple Single EP
label: Gold Metal
description: On the Quadruple Single EP, Seattle's Big Business, now a quartet, don't get the melody-to-sludge quotient quite right.

title: The Glad Birth of Love
label: Empty Cellar
description: Fresh & Onlys frontman's latest breaks the steady solo-record routine he's established over the last several years with a set of long-form suites. [Aaron Leitko]

title: Outside Society
label: Columbia
description: In the wake of her National Book Award for the memoir Just Kids comes a single-disc compilation that attempts to encapsulate the pioneering punk's sprawling and uneven musical career. But the abridgement leaves us with a rock'n'roll throwback that's sturdy but not particularly flexible.

title: Endless Now
label: Sub Pop
description: Recording with John Agnello (Dinosaur Jr., Kurt Vile), the British punks clean up their sound a bit on their latest Sub Pop LP.

title: Tha Carter IV
label: Cash Money
description: After last year's prison stint-- not to mention the disappointing rock experiment Rebirth and various underwhelming stop-gap releases-- Lil Wayne finally attempts to reassert his hip-hop supremacy with Tha Carter IV.

title: Figure It Out
label: Paper Bag
description: This early-career rarities comp from the Ontario band serves two purposes: Its first side shines a light on the band's pre-Muster Station origins, while the second brings us up to date on what the band has been up to since that album's release.

title: Lounge Lizards EP
label: Mexican Summer
description: Mike Polizze, the man behind Purling Hiss, has tapped into a trashy aesthetic that's part of rock'n'roll's DNA. Here, the Kurt Vile associate from Philadelphia burrows deeper into warped, scuzzy rock'n'roll and late-night burnout introspection.

title: Tassili
label: Anti-
description: The Malian desert guitar band changes things up with acoustic instrumentation and guest spots from Nels Cline and members of TV on the Radio. The invitation of outsiders into the songs is in one sense a measure of the confidence the band has in the integrity and singularity of its sound, and also a reflection of where they've been recently.

title: The R.E.D. Album
label: DGC
description: After many delays, Game returns with an utter mess of an LP, one heavy on guests (Drake, Rick Ross, Tyler, the Creator) and light on inspiration. The perverse thing about The R.E.D. Album is that amidst this unsightly storm of star power is the backbone of what could've been a coherent album.

title: Wander / Wonder
label: Tri Angle
description: Balam Acab, the project of 20-year-old Pennsylvanian Alec Koone, was slotted with witch house when he released his See Birds EP in 2010. Here, his primary concern is simple aesthetic beauty, the way a small and specific combination of sounds, carefully arranged but given room to breathe, can have a deep emotional impact.

title: Through Donkey Jaw
label: Sacred Bones
description: After the release of 2009's DIA, Damon McMahon returned to America from China and formed a band, resulting in a fuller sound on his latest. He's still making muffled, eerie pop akin to the private visions of Syd Barrett and Skip Spence but its 14 songs are sharper and fuller, with quicker access to your brain's pleasure center.

title: I Am an Attic
label: self-released
description: The busy collaborator and frontman (Mister Heavenly, Human Highway, Islands, etc.) steps out with a low-key pay-what-you-want solo album. While it doesn't come with the pre-packaged, stylistic framework of, say, Human Highway (read: Young, Neil; 1970s folk and country), I Am An Attic does scan as pure Diamonds.

title: Coastal Grooves
label: Domino
description: Dev Hynes follows Test Icicles and Lightspeed Champion with a new solo project, a highly stylish album that frequently forgoes things like melodies, energy, and vocal choruses in favor of slinky, solitary guitar lines and seductively spare, post-punk atmospherics.

title: You Are All I See
label: Vagrant
description: Following on the Curtis Lane EP, the Denver-based singer and producer releases his full-length debut, and it mixes ethereal choir-like vocals and minimal R&B with currents of rumbling post-dubstep. But the allusions to modern trends are so well-realized that it creates a slightly numbing impression of pastiche.

title: XXX
label: Fool's Gold
description: The audacious Detroit rapper with a strangled voice and a penchant for depravity transforms his jagged edges into a compelling and immersive universe. Brown's voice is uniquely suited to conveying wild-eyed, loose-cannon insanity, and the rising note of panic in it makes every mention of snorting crushed Adderall hurt.

title: Still Living
label: Lefse
description: Sactown janglers Ganglians conceived Still Living, their nearly hour-long third LP, as something of a clearinghouse. The guitar-pop band has a slack in its step and a strong feel for melody, mixing Byrdsian folk-psych, loose-limbed 80s indie rock, and fizzy Beach Boys-derived harmonies.

title: The Ornament
label: Hardly Art
description: Arthur & Yu crooner Grant Olsen has a new folk-rock project featuring assistance from Papercuts frontman Jason Quever. Previous release In Camera was a charming effort, but also a relatively small-sounding one; here, melodies seem to stretch across highways and its drums so hollow you could live within them.

title: West
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Wooden Shjips turn the crunchy choogle of 1970s boogie-rock into isolation-chamber space-out fare. When it connects, that's a powerful formula. On West, the SF space-rockers make their biggest leap toward approachability, creating the first Wooden Shjips album your stoner uncle might not hate.

title: Hearts
label: Bella Union
description: Swedish duo I Break Horses immerse themselves in homemade shoegaze, the kind that's made by computers for computers. It's an approach and sound that's crossed language barriers for the past 20 or so years as bands strive to approximate Loveless without the benefit of a label they can bankrupt in the process.

title: Thursday
label: self-released
description: The drugged-up R&B project returns with its second free album, picking up where House of Balloons left off and adding some new twists. There's the same ineffably skeezy vibe and a genuine sense of the album-as-journey, and the production is slightly harsher and streaked with violence, befitting the lyrical content.

title: Don't Act Like You Don't Care
label: Western Vinyl
description: While he was recording his debut as Here We Go Magic, Luke Temple simultaneously made another solo album with a few friends helping him out, including future Here We Go Magic member Michael Bloch and Glass Ghost's Eliot Krimsky. Temple shelved the results, Don't Act Like You Don't Care, until the present day.

title: Wigry
label: Bôłt
description: MIMEO is an acronym for Music in Movement Electronic Orchestra, and here the long-running experimental supergroup featuring Keith Rowe, Christian Fennesz, Rafael Toral, and more creates abstract improvisations in a Polish church.

title: Ugly Buildings, Whores & Politicians: Greatest Hits 1998-2009
label: New West
description: Drive-By Truckers' first career retrospective seems too short, but Ugly Buildings still attests to the breadth of the band's music, which ranges in style from gritty rock to Southern soul and ranges in subject from racial politics to recession worries.

title: Widowspeak
label: Captured Tracks
description: Widowspeak's captivating singer Molly Hammilton conjures Mazzy Star's Hope Sandoval but the key to this crestfallen Brooklyn trio is the guitar work. The skill with which Widowspeak assimilates its influences into alluring song structures is what prevents this from being an exercise in tributary.

title: Out of Love
label: Sub Pop
description: The "doom wop" project of Nick Thorburn (Islands/Unicorns), Ryan Kattner (Man Man), and Joe Plummer (Modest Mouse) offers a focused, engaging debut. Rather than serve as an outlet for their well-documented eccentric streaks, Thorburn and Kattner's good-cop/bad-cop dynamic yields some of the most tightly focused songs either principal has produced.

title: Program 91
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: The youthful debut from this indie-pop quartet from Norway (the band is made up of 19-year-old girls who have known each other since they were six and have been making music together since they were 14) is an exercise in writing what you know.

title: Tripper
label: Sub Pop
description: With Tripper, the group's fifth album, Fruit Bats dial their pulse back down, favoring spacious and spacey songwriting that sets the lyrics front and center. It's a record full of stories, simple narratives, and offbeat characters.

title: Hollow
label: Frenchkiss
description: The New Zealand band's sweeping, airy indie rock is far removed from the implied violence of their name, and their second LP, sounds much closer to the late-1980s/early-90s work of British rock bands in the vein of Kitchens of Distinction, the House of Love, and the Trash Can Sinatras.

title: Ferrari Boyz
label: Warner Bros.
description: This is the first full-length collaboration between the rappers, whose styles are almost completely opposite. If Gucci painted pictures, Waka looks at a blank canvas and dumps a can of red paint on it. Then maybe breaks it over his knee.

title: Slave Ambient
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Slidin'. Ramblin'. Driftin'. Movin'. Strugglin'. The War on Drugs frontman Adam Granduciel is all of these things on Slave Ambient, the Philly outfit's second full-length release. But they're the sort of band that believes the journey is more important than the destination.

title: Atlantic EP
label: Cascine
description: Canadian synth-pop duo Southern Shores want to be your summer vacation.

title: Watch Me Dance
label: Ninja Tune
description: Sheffield producer Toddla T's sophomore album is is an eclectic mix of dance throwbacks fleshed out by a roster of veteran guest vocalists.

title: Revisited & Remixed (1970-1999)
label: SPV
description: On the 10th anniversary of Florian Fricke's death, a collection of the German avant gardists' thrilling original recordings plus a disc of prosaic remixes.

title: Leave No Trace
label: IAMSOUND
description: For their second Fool's Gold full-length, Lewis Pesacov, Luke Top, and co. tone down the Afro-pop and basically made a Foreign Born record.

title: Mirror Traffic
label: Matador
description: Stephen Malkmus' Beck-produced Mirror Traffic possesses a relaxed, spontaneous feel befitting the Pavement frontman's earlier days.

title: Marble Son
label: Fargo
description: Jesse Sykes & the Sweet Hereafter's fourth album favors oddly shaped jams and is their heaviest to date.

title: Amplifying Host
label: Jagjaguwar
description: On Amplifying Host, British experimentalist Richard Youngs takes his devotion to a single approach to the microscopic level.

title: Yucca
label: Fat Cat
description: The solo project of UK "post-grunge" crew Nine Black Alps' bassist Martin Cohen basks in the influence of 1990s lo-fi greats.

title: Closer to Closed
label: Polyvinyl
description: The influential 1990s Illinois band is back: Longtime fans will be crying for the wrong reasons.

title: Not the Spaces You Know, But Between Them
label: Three Lobed
description: The Three Lobed label celebrates 10 years in business with a comp including unreleased material from Sonic Youth, Sun City Girls, Comets on Fire, and more.

title: Breaking the Frame
label: Dynamic Tension
description: Surgeon's first album in a decade foregrounds the chilly austerity associated with the veteran British producer's name throughout the late 1990s.

title: GIVING
label: Hometapes
description: The expansive Wisconsin band says goodbye to two members and hello to new fans with these triumphal, hard-charging post-Volcano Choir recordings.

title: Bad Vibes
label: Friends of Friends
description: The L.A. producer's second LP dredges up a jaggedly delicate sound that merges gently wafting electronic tones with intricately decaying rhythmic atmosphere.

title: Gainsbourg Percussions
label: 4 Men With Beards
description: On Serge Gainsbourg's 1964 African-and-Latin-inspired Percussions, we hear the innovative artist that the salacious details sometimes obscure.

title: Watch the Throne
label: Def Jam
description: Maybe you've heard of this one? This meeting of two long-reigning titans is the kind of stadium-sized event-rap spectacle we don't get often enough.

title: Cult of Youth
label: Sacred Bones
description: Cult of Youth's rollicking eponymous LP is the charismatic post-punk group's second full-length, but it might be better to treat it as a debut.

title: Love Has Made Me Stronger
label: Drag City
description: More than three decades after self-releasing her debut, the hippie harpist signed her first record deal for this Drag City reissue.

title: Ghosts Outside
label: Double Six
description: The onetime Beta Band vocalist reworks last year's solo folk-rock effort Boys Outside with the help of UK-based dub veteran Dennis Bovell.

title: Greneberg
label: Decon
description: On the Greneberg EP, three talented artists (Roc Marciano, Alchemist, and Oh No) create hard, dusty, uncompromising, chaotic underground rap.

title: Family of Love EP
label: Astralwerks
description: For their second EP, Worcester's favorite indie-pop slackers hand in a surprisingly ambitious, detail-packed, Nicholas Vernhes-produced collection.

title: Forever Dolphin Love
label: Because
description: Young hypna-delic New Zealander Connan Mockasin's languid, mind-submerged Forever Dolphin Love is the work of someone sounding small but dreaming big.

title: Response
label: !K7
description: Quasi-anonymous electro-rock newcomer Dave.I.D's jaggedly careening Response is a visceral work of crimson emotion and apocalyptic drama.

title: Chill Out Zone
label: Elusive
description: UK Charts-flirting grime staple Wiley follows recent offering 100% Publishing with a self-released "EP" of soul-searching rap over sugar-coated beats.

title: Our Blood
label: Merge
description: Richard Buckner was forced to make Our Blood-- his most concise, driven, and well-considered album in the last decade-- three times.

title: It / Freaks / Separations
label: Fire
description: Pulp are ignoring the early albums in their reunion, but these recordings from 1983 to 1992 offer an important look at the band's development and reinvention.

title: Native To
label: Downtown
description: London trio Is Tropical is fashion-forward French label Kitsuné's latest attempt to merge the worlds of dance and rock music.

title: As the Crow Flies
label: Ghost Box
description: On an album inspired by seasonal stasis and change, acoustic instrumentation pushes Advisory Circle's electronics into a darkly pastoral place.

title: You Were a Dick
label: Idaho Music
description: The first Idaho album in six years finds the longstanding slowcore crew-- now the solo project of founder Jeff Martin-- in a wry, pensively melancholic place.

title: Trouble Books and Mark McGuire
label: Bark and Hiss
description: The Cleveland-based guitarist and Emeralds member joins up with the Akron-based husband-and-wife duo for a collaborative, self-released LP.

title: The Rip Tide
label: Pompeii
description: Beirut's defiantly small third studio album finds a restrained, stately Zach Condon displaying his antiquated fantasies on slightly shrunken canvases.

title: The Lateness of the Hour
label: Island
description: Young UK crooner Alex Clare's The Lateness of the Hour, featuring production from Diplo and Switch, comes off like a Ray LaMontagne record with beats.

title: Parabolas
label: Kompakt
description: The L.A. transplant's Kompakt debut LP collects 12 tech-house instrumentals, which can act as a form of comedown comfort food.

title: King of Hearts
label: Interscope
description: On his Polow Da Don-produced King of Hearts, the endearlngly romantic vocalist makes a bid for a higher level of R&B-world recognition.

title: Plays "High Gospel"
label: Constellation
description: Godspeed You! Black Emperor/Thee Silver Mt. Zionist's solo debut recalls John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band.

title: Must Be Blind / The Mindeater / There Is No God 10"
label: Drag City
description: Three recent Will Oldham releases highlight how he has managed to make inconsistency part of his artistic identity.

title: Peanut Butter and Swelly
label: Datpiff.com
description: Philly rap duo Chiddy Bang's mixtape pairs a disregard for language with indie-baiting production.

title: Body EP
label: Hippos in Tanks
description: On his Body EP, unidentified New York-based R&B imploder Autre Ne Veut pushes messily human pop exclamations to the forefront.

title: They Came From the Sky
label: Sacred Bones
description: Sci-fi-friendly Detroit garage rockers Human Eye's focus on extraterrestrials has finally been matched by an equally exacting focus on music.

title: Let It Beard
label: Guided By Voices, Inc.
description: On album five, Guided By Voices frontman Robert Pollard's power-pop band Boston Spaceships take a stab at a classic double LP.

title: iTunes Session
label: Capitol
description: A few months after chart-topper The King Is Dead, the Oregon indie folk band's new eight-song EP includes covers of Leonard Cohen and Fruit Bats.

title: Volume One 1970-1979
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Assembled by Thrill Jockey and Bamba himself, this compilation spans some of Mali's diverse musical traditions, updated in the 1970s with guitars and organs.

title: Howl of the Lonely Crowd
label: What's Your Rupture?
description: UK indie pop lifers team with Orange Juice's Edwyn Collins, the Cribs' Ryan Jarman, and others for their first new album since 2005.

title: Soft Metals
label: Captured Tracks
description: The Portland duo's beguiling Captured Tracks debut LP bears traces of virtually every bleakly gliding descendant of Kraftwerk's original synth-pop grooves.

title: Last Words: The Final Recordings
label: Sunyata
description: This collection of previously unreleased late-90s Screaming Trees recordings offers an epitaph for a band that died of natural causes.

title: Science of the Sea
label: Digitalis
description: This record, initially issued in a small run in the early 80s, is richly evocative of the natural world and holds up as an immersive ambient experience.

title: Last Night on Earth
label: Ojet
description: The Brooklyn dream-pop veterans recruit the Antibalas horns, Jeff Buckley drummer Matt Johnson, and members of Bon Iver and Antony and the Johnsons.

title: Field Songs
label: Anti-
description: William Elliott Whitmore, a banjo-toting folkie raised on hardcore, sings about hammers, steamboats, and dying in a deep, gnarled, energizing voice.

title: Afro Noise I
label: Very Friendly
description: The more you know about the new solo project from William Bennett, founding member of UK noise group Whitehouse, the deeper and richer the music sounds.

title: Legendary Weapons
label: E1
description: With new verses from almost every top Clansman, Wu-Tang's latest isn't an odds-and-sods LP, but it isn't a proper follow-up to 2007's 8 Diagrams, either.

title: Organ Music Not Vibraphone Like I'd Hoped
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Spencer Krug's project away from Sunset Rubdown and the on-hiatus Wolf Parade continues to obsess over the properties of specific instruments.

title: Together/Apart
label: Rhymesayers
description: The rapper's first album for Rhymesayers (and third overall) zeroes in on the drudgery of being broke, kicking addictions, and getting over ex-girlfriends.

title: Please Stop Loving Me
label: Streamline
description: This album of bright, hymn-like drone is mesmerizing but also oddly challenging, with constantly shifting textures that invite steady attention.

title: Come Back to Us
label: Brushfire
description: The Rogue Wave frontman makes a solo album and captures some of what made his main band's early records interesting.

title: Satin Panthers EP
label: Warp
description: Amid attention from mainstream hip-hop, the Glasgow producer's latest shows he has improved markedly since 2009 debut Butter.

title: Icky Mettle
label: Merge
description: The Archers' searing 1993 debut still stands as a high-water mark in 90s indie rock, and is augmented on this deluxe reissue with a key EP and singles.

title: Famous First Words
label: Geffen
description: Hyped UK band tries to recapture the glory days of Britpop and fails rather miserably.

title: Bent
label: self-released
description: Latest album from the Kansas City, Missouri, multimedia art project playfully mixes disco and attitude-heavy electro pop.

title: Prom
label: Kanine
description: For its follow-up to 2009 debut Rejoicer, the Brooklyn trio dives headlong into the sweeping erotic confusion of 1990s alt-rock's dreamier set.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: Moving from Sun Ra to old-school IDM to Afrobeat to ambient house, MCDE's entry in the DJ-Kicks series is eclectic as hell but manages to feel unified.

title: BlackenedWhite [Reissue]
label: Fat Possum
description: The Odd Future project's 2010 album has been re-shuffled and remastered with two additional tracks for release on Fat Possum.

title: Meine Zarten Pfoten
label: Pampa
description: Rather than embrace her techno past or more fully flesh out the mixed-genre approach of 2009's Adaptations, Ada goes soft pop on her new LP.

title: Joint Ventures
label: Build
description: Bristol-via-Manchester bass producer Baobinga's first LP on his Build label is crammed with so many collaborations he shares the artist credit.

title: Capricorn Rising EP
label: Italians Do It Better
description: The New Jersey-based founder of the labels Troubleman Unlimited, Italians Do It Better, and Perseo steps out with an atmospheric post-disco EP.

title: Running Blind EP
label: Nonesuch
description: Radiohead drummer follows his solo debut, last year's Familial, with four more tracks of singer-songwriter fare, now slightly more open to textures.

title: What's Going On [40th Anniversary Edition]
label: Interscope
description: The classic 1971 LP, a landmark for Gaye and pop music at large, is reissued in a deluxe package including an early mix and demos.

title: Canopy EP
label: Secretly Canadian
description: This Bay Area duo is another entry in the post-Animal Collective dream-pop stakes, with swirling electronics and songs about water and sleep.

title: Gold Rings and Fur Pelts
label: Syren
description: Montreal singer-songwriter works with scene vet Sam Shalabi and others in the Constellation stable on an album of colorful psych-folk.

title: The Last Place
label: Fever Zone
description: Familiarity mostly works in the L.A. indie popsters' favor on their taut, tuneful second album, a song cycle about a relationship gone awry.

title: Through the Green
label: Running Back
description: This reclusive duo takes a crowd-pleasing approach to disco edits, packing its tracks with nothing but generous highlights.

title: Sorry 4 the Wait
label: Unknown
description: Unlike Dedication 2 or Da Drought 3, Wayne's new mixtape sounds like the work of a mortal-- who raps very well.

title: Total
label: Big Beat
description: The Ed Banger-affiliated French producer's debut album is packed with nasty-sounding, repetition-heavy grindhouse electro.

title: Night Gallery
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The Portland-bred space-rockers and Long Beach-based vibe merchant come together for a 40-minute Austin jam session, with trippy results.

title: Random Axe
label: Duckdown
description: Hip-hop supergroup comprising Brooklyn's Sean Price, Detroit's Guilty Simpson, and Black Milk finally releases its long-gestating debut.

title: Ritual Union
label: Peacefrog
description: Sweden's Little Dragon have a distinct and immediately alluring style, and on their third album, they double down on their futuristic pop sound.

title: Just Once EP
label: Love Letters Ink
description: Tom Krell follows 2010's terrific Love Remains with a low-key, four-song release that affirms there is something special about this project.

title: 3 EP
label: 4AD
description: Debut 4AD EP from the L.A. brothers and Prince acolytes turns out to be a maximalist grotesquerie of minimal sounds.

title: Room(s)
label: Planet Mu
description: Versatile producer infuses his tricky beats with in-vogue vocal samples, which turns out to be both good and bad.

title: Actually
label: Underwater Peoples
description: A cosmopolitan approach to making music yields kaleidoscopic results on this atmospheric dream-pop debut.

title: Timesup EP
label: Fade to Mind
description: A new EP featuring three original tracks and two remixes from the production duo behind a number of eclectic and forward-thinking mixes.

title: Skying
label: XL
description: The Horrors tone down the experiments of Primary Colours for a record with obvious stylistic debts and impeccable taste.

title: Family and Friends
label: Anticon
description: Produced by WHY's Yoni Wolf and Casiotone for the Painfully Alone's Owen Ashworth, the Chicago MC's solo Anticon debut marks a return of sorts for the label.

title: First Edition
label: Chemikal Underground
description: Members of the Twilight Sad, Frightened Rabbit, the Delgados, and Idlewild come together for a one-off album united by a common theme.

title: To What Strange Place: The Music of the Ottoman-American Diaspora, 1916-1929
label: Tompkins Square
description: This 3xCD box set compiled by 78 collector Ian Nagoski chronicles the experience of Ottoman immigrants in the early 20th century.

title: Bermuda Drain
label: Hydra Head
description: Dominick Fernow's latest one-man recording is... pleasant, and not only by contrast with his old unholy racket.

title: Section.80
label: Top Dawg
description: The Compton-based, Dr. Dre-affiliated rapper steps out with a pop-rap debut that puts a futuristic spin on 90s alt-rap.

title: Mirror Mirror
label: Domino
description: The Glasgow band's macabre spirit remains on its third LP, which recalls gothic post-punks like Siouxsie and the Banshees, Joy Division, and Bauhaus.

title: Sam Baker's Album
label: Brainfeeder
description: The young producer with some promising EPs under his belt steps out with a full-length on Flying Lotus' Brainfeeder imprint.

title: FRKWYS Vol. 7
label: Rvng Intl.
description: The latest in the RVNG's series of improv collabs between experimental music veterans and their contemporary counterparts includes minimalist David Borden.

title: Writings on the Wall II
label: Datpiff.com
description: The Atlanta rapper's latest mixtape adapts his unique approach to a more aggro era by tapping Brick Squad mixtape mercenaries Lex Luger and Southside.

title: Peace Sells... But Who's Buying? [25th Anniversary Edition]
label: Capitol
description: Circa 1986 was a very good time for metal, and Megadeth's awesome entry from that year has been given an expanded reissue.

title: Staring Into the Sun
label: Sublime Frequencies
description: In a DVD, a CD, notes, and photographs, the filmmaker/photographer documents the music of 13 Ethiopian tribes with extraordinary thoroughness.

title: nyc stuff and nyc bags
label: R&S
description: The second EP from this once-mysterious London trio is more refined than last year's Sauna, with elements of Balearic, R&B, and UK garage.

title: Pearls & Embarrassments: 2000-2010
label: Monkeytown
description: This career-spanning compilation finds the genre-averse Berlin electronic producer revealing an impressively favorable ratio of pearls to embarrassments.

title: Seven Stars
label: Touch
description: This brief four-track EP finds Christian Fennesz in lyrical mode, using his processed guitar to evoke a memory-washed vision of pop.

title: When Fish Ride Bicycles
label: Green Label Sound
description: The Chicago retro-rap duo has been promising the imminent arrival of a proper debut album for so long it felt reasonable to assume it would never show up.

title: Mindreading
label: Drag City
description: Featuring former members of 90 Day Men and U.S. Maple, the Chicago band retains an air of inscrutability on its second Drag City album.

title: Hello Cruel World
label: Fake Four
description: On his latest LP, Sole collaborates with Lil B and Pictureplane and rhymes over diffuse synthetic soul from the Skyrider Band.

title: Nightdolls with Hairspray / On Air
label: Olde English Spelling Bee
description: Hypnogogic pop maven explores his mysterious, hyper-referential 1980s sound on a new album and a recent vinyl reissue.

title: Thee Physical
label: Lovepump United
description: With help from HEALTH's Jupiter Keyes, Denver producer Travis Egedy refines the blasted-electro approach of 2009's Dark Rift.

title: Leave Home
label: Sacred Bones
description: On their latest album, Brooklyn's Men put their own spin on the raw and ragged sound of noisy 1980s indie rock to delirious effect.

title: Wayward Fire
label: Modern Art
description: The band name suggests throwback pop, but the era in question is actually the 1980s, and Chain Gang of 1974's emulation of it is both impressive and its undoing.

title: Dorus Rijkers EP
label: Atlantic Jaxx
description: Basement Jaxx half Simon Ratcliffe's new solo EP is another reminder why the house duo's unconventional spirit once made dance classicists turn up their noses.

title: Nupping
label: HOSS
description: The Baltimore-based noise-punk quartet uses pedals, loops, and off-kilter rhythms to pummel its teenage heroes into blurry abstraction on its debut album.

title: Red Hot + Rio 2
label: E1
description: The 12th volume in the series dedicated to AIDS awareness features Madlib, David Byrne, Tom Zé, Of Montreal, and more collaborating on Tropicália updates.

title: I'm Gay (I'm Happy)
label: BasedWorld
description: The hyper-prolific rapper with an endless number of YouTube freestyles finds a new focus and crafts his most accessible album.

title: Invasion of the Mysteron Killer Sounds
label: Soul Jazz
description: Two longtime advocates for Jamaican music, Kevin "The Bug" Martin and Soul Jazz head Stuart Baker, highlight dancehall's global evolution on this 2xCD set.

title: Was I the Wave?
label: Secret City
description: Four years after earning a Polaris nomination for debut Five Roses, Montreal's Graham Van Pelt returns with a follow-up as sleek as it is introverted.

title: N-Plants
label: Touch
description: The Norwegian producer's latest album, prophetically inspired by Japanese nuclear power plants, is his best since 1997 ambient milestone Substrata.

title: Whatever's on Your Mind
label: ATO
description: After developing something of a rep as homespun MOR lifers, the former Mercury Prize winners look to bring it all back home.

title: Lifes Rich Pageant (25th Anniversary Edition)
label: Capitol
description: R.E.M.'s pivotal 1986 album is remastered and reissued with an intriguing bonus disc of full-band demos.

title: Doubles
label: VHF
description: This Irish steel-string guitarist sometimes reminiscent of James Blackshaw and Jim O'Rourke steps out with an LP containing two epic side-long compositions.

title: Again and Again
label: Slumberland
description: SF's Brilliant Colors, easy to lose among the deluge of indie pop bands on Slumberland, return with a solid second album.

title: Torches
label: Columbia
description: With a few catchy singles, the demonstratively upbeat L.A. trio's first album dares you to categorize them, assess them, or even engage with them.

title: Last Summer
label: Merge
description: The Fiery Furnaces singer's solo debut feels like a throwback to idiosyncratic, solidly crafted singer-songwriter LPs from the 1970s.

title: Dedication
label: 4AD
description: On his debut for the 4AD label, the UK producer releases his strangest, most low-key, and least dance-friendly record.

title: Rave On: A Tribute to Buddy Holly
label: Fantasy
description: Julian Casablancas, Modest Mouse, Lou Reed, Kid Rock, and many more cover big tunes by Buddy Holly with dispiriting results.

title: Virtue
label: Close Harbour
description: London singer-songwriter Emma-Lee Moss' second album follows a broken engagement to a man who decided to become a missionary.

title: Are You Falling in Love?
label: Slumberland
description: Atlanta indie pop group's debut LP sounds beamed in straight from 1993, favoring the dreamy, moody, blurry sounds of the early to mid-1990s.

title: Two-Way Mirror
label: Recreation Ltd.
description: After releasing the final new LP on Touch and Go, Crystal Antlers return with a looser, more experimental record that plays to their strengths.

title: Within and Without
label: Sub Pop
description: Two years after helping to define a genre with the Life of Leisure EP, Ernest Greene returns with a satisfying full-length expansion of his sound.

title: Who's Gonna Save the World
label: Numero Group
description: Numero Group unearths a transfixing unreleased 1973 debut from a psychedelic soul band from Washington, D.C.

title: Glacial Glow
label: Weird Forest
description: Prolific drone artist Sarah Lipstate comes into her own with her best and most distinctive record yet.

title: 116 & Rising
label: Hessle
description: UK bass label Hessle Audio offers its first full-length release: one disc of classic label cuts and another of new material.

title: Kingston Story
label: Mixpak
description: The Jamaican DJ's new album is less exhaustingly morose than 2009's Pon Di Gaza, but it's also more tepid, both lyrically and sonically.

title: We Must Become the Pitiless Censors of Ourselves
label: Ribbon Music/Upset the Rhythm
description: The avant-pop songwriter whose career has intersected with that of Ariel Pink focuses on melody and delivers a delightfully weird full-length.

title: OX 2010: A Street Odyssey
label: Fat Beats
description: One-half of legendary indie-rap duo Cannibal Ox follows 2008's Dueces Wild with an album that briefly features CanOx partner Vordul Mega.

title: Waco Taco Combo
label: Escho
description: Sonic collagist and Black Dice member's latest LP boasts some of his catchiest songs to date.

title: Is This Hyperreal?
label: Digital Hardcore
description: The German electro-punks' first album in years is a curious thing indeed: a nostalgic work that evokes an idea of the future that turned out to be absurd.

title: SBTRKT
label: Young Turks
description: UK producer's debut full-length inches closer to pop than his post-dubstep contemporaries James Blake or Jamie Woon.

title: Player Piano
label: Carpark
description: Following on Seek Magic, his satisfying debut of hazy dream-pop, Memory Tapes' Dayve Hawk goes for more of a full-band sound with mixed results.

title: Gardens & Villa
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Mixing gothic mysticism and hazy dream pop, Gardens & Villa step out with a promising full-length debut.

title: Stranger Ballet
label: Afternoon
description: The tirelessly touring Iowa indie rockers follow 2010's sprawiing Sad Sour Future with a sharper, more streamlined album.

title: Finally Famous
label: Def Jam
description: The likable Detroit rapper's debut on Kanye West's G.O.O.D. Music features West, The-Dream, Lupe Fiasco, Wiz Khalifa, Pusha T, and more.

title: Pleasure
label: Acéphale
description: The name of this Austin trio has changed, but their delayed-gratification summer vibes have only become more refined and elemental on this welcome debut LP.

title: Electronic Dream
label: Duke
description: Producer behind the recent reemergence of Dipset and Cam'ron strikes out on his own, making lush instrumentals with his own fully developed aesthetic.

title: Ceremony
label: Innovative Leisure
description: Ernest Gonzales' debut LP as Mexicans With Guns aims for the cinematic but lacks nuance and pacing.

title: Evening Tapestry
label: Slumberland
description: The debut from this Philadelphia indie pop group owes a debt to the gentle psych-pop of the Elephant 6 collective.

title: Shangri-La
label: DFA
description: The Portland duo's second DFA album fuses a utopian concept with nervy, spastic electro-funk.

title: Galactic Melt
label: Ghostly
description: Prolific Princeton, N.J., artist releases his debut full-length, which works as a polite companion to his Cyanide Sisters EP.

title: Drums Between the Bells
label: Warp
description: On his latest album for Warp, the legendary sonic architect teams with poet Rick Holland for an inconsistent but occasionally brilliant set.

title: Alchemic Heart
label: Important
description: The Japanese 11-piece's first readily available release consists of two dramatic 24-minute tracks, featuring ex-Swans singer Jarboe and noise lord Merzbow.

title: Me Doing Standup
label: Comedy Central
description: The death-obsessed everyman's comedy LP is typically indulgent and frequently hilarious.

title: 100% Publishing
label: Big Dada
description: Created outside any sort of label system, the UK grime godfather's latest is his first album distributed by Big Dada since 2007's Playtime Is Over.

title: The Unanimous Hour
label: Dischord
description: Remastered and reissued by Dischord, the Baltimore post-hardcore band's long-out-of-print eighth record is a good entry point to its singular catalog.

title: Lord Giveth, Lord Taketh Away EP
label: CTE
description: Freddie Gibbs teams up with East Coast producer Statik Selektah to record an EP in a single day.

title: Two Matchsticks
label: Barsuk
description: Former American Analog Set leader Andrew Kenny turns in a second solo set of clear, unadorned lessons about life and love. Matt Pond and Ben Gibbard guest.

title: Living: 2009-Present
label: Thin Wrist
description: Devout students of 1980s goth and industrial, the attention-getting L.A. duo strings together a hodge-podge of live takes on its first full-length release.

title: Lights Out
label: Hello?Repeat
description: More than a decade into her career, this Chicago-reared DJ and recording artist shows her formative house influence on a debut born in Buenos Aires.

title: Exmilitary
label: Third Worlds
description: With drumming by Zach Hill (Hella, Marnie Stern), the Sacramento punk-rap outfit offers a bludgeoning slab of hostility on its free mixtape.

title: Weekend at Burnie's
label: Warner Bros.
description: The absurdly prolific and consistent rapper returns with a major label record and more songs about weed and everyday life.

title: Alice, Agatha, Branch & Christ
label: self-released
description: With a fun-loving brand of lo-fi guitar pop, the Seattle band's promising eight-song album can stand beside the work of the indie-pop heroes of yesteryear.

title: D
label: Downtown
description: Following the addition of a second guitarist and a move to an actual studio, the Austin band's fourth album is its best-sounding yet, all groovy Texas psych.

title: Debut
label: Honest Jon's
description: A far cry from Delay's vocal-house project Luomo, Debut is nonetheless a surprisingly enveloping and immediately rewarding album.

title: Sound Kapital
label: Sub Pop
description: With Wolf Parade on indefinite hiatus, Dan Boeckner gives his full attention to Handsome Furs, and they craft their best album yet.

title: New Brigade
label: What's Your Rupture?
description: On their debut LP, this young band from Denmark mixes post-punk clang and goth atmosphere, serving it up with a massive dose of addictive energy.

title: Sagara
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: The Oslo-based producer known for crisp space disco tries his hand at Gamelan-inspired ambient music.

title: The Miners' Hymns
label: Fat Cat
description: The Icelandic composer's score for Bill Morrison's film about coal mining in northern England will not make a stellar accompaniment to your next barbecue.

title: Pl3dge
label: SMC
description: The one-time OutKast associate sounds comfortable in a more underground role and mixes sharp political observations with an appealing musical sense.

title: Carbonated EP
label: Hotflush
description: The UK duo's latest pairs a selection from Crooks & Lovers with two new tracks, plus remixes from the bass-music and minimal techno realms.

label: Columbia
description: It's a more mature album with songs about the intricacies of relationships, but 4 has its share of stunning tracks, many co-written by The-Dream.

title: Shirts vs. Skins
label: File Under: Music
description: Tokyo Police Club's keyboardist makes his solo debut with a record of straightforward power-pop.

title: Hour Logic EP
label: Hippos in Tanks
description: On the follow up to her debut EP, Laurel Halo ditches conventional melody for dark, propulsive rhythms and lets her beats run wild.

title: Thora Vukk
label: Pampa
description: German electronic music veteran's second album is an elegant, eminently listenable blend of chirpy beats, homespun voices, and sighing keyboards.

title: Blanck Mass
label: Rock Action
description: Fuck Buttons' Benjamin John Power offers his solo debut as Blanck Mass, working in a slower paced ambient vein to hypnotic effect.

title: Black Up
label: Sub Pop
description: After two fine EPs, the experimental hip-hop project helmed by former Digable Planets leader Ishmael Butler steps out with a brilliant full-length debut.

title: I Love You, Dude
label: V2
description: The Hamburg duo's sophomore album adds bromance to the blog-house of 2007 debut Idealism, a house-rock hybrid recalling Justice or Simian Mobile Disco.

title: Memories Come True
label: Drag City
description: Duo behind the eclectic psych-pop group Lights offers this debut under its new moniker, rife with 70s power-pop, 80s sheen, and slack 90s rock.

title: Mount Moriah
label: Holidays for Quince
description: Bellafea's Heather McEntire leaves the spartan postpunk of that band in favor of more traditional folk, country, and gospel sounds on this new project.

title: Tamer Animals
label: TBD
description: Meticulously written and arranged, the wistful Americana of the sophomore album from this Oklahoma group feels organic and lovingly crafted.

title: Coming Up [Deluxe Edition] / Head Music [Deluxe Edition] / A New Morning [Deluxe Edition]
label: Demon
description: The latest in the Suede reissue series show a band that remained creative and worthy in the wake of what could have been a fatal loss.

title: Fania Records 1964-1980: The Original Sound of Latin New York
label: Strut
description: Strut's new 2xCD compilation documents the rise of salsa, with key tracks by Willie Colón, Rubén Blades, Héctor Lavoe, and others.

title: H–p1
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The New York space-rock explorers seek to capture a loud, exhilarating, and unhinged live show on their second Thrill Jockey album.

title: Fjree Feather
label: No Pain in Pop
description: Reissue of Matthew Barnes' pre-Dagger Paths work includes six early Forest Swords tracks, and the proceeds go to Red Cross tsunami relief.

title: Digital Lows
label: Fat Sandwich
description: Memphis rapper proves himself a conflicted thinker, with an outsider/insider perspective that merges the personal and the political.

title: Go Tell Fire to the Mountain
label: L Y F
description: These mysterious Mancunians craft a debut of exhilarating expanse and passion that sounds like indie rock and yet feels way bigger.

title: Gimme Ten
label: self-released
description: Norwegian band offers a free album made up of 10 songs that are each around one minute long.

title: One Night in the Borough
label: Delusions of Grandeur
description: Scottish production duo's debut album feels like a quintessentially of-the-moment dissertation on deepness in house music.

title: BOBBY
label: Partisan
description: Art-folk group's debut plays upon the disparities between ambient and rhythmic, airy and earthy, restive and tranquil.

title: Limerence
label: Alpha Pup
description: UK beat-fiddler's production shares plenty in common with Californians Flying Lotus and Daedelus, abounding in left turns and outré sounds.

title: Unknown Mortal Orchestra
label: Fat Possum
description: On its promising debut full-length, this Portland outfit mixes catchy psych-pop with a surprising and convincing undercurrent of funk.

title: Lovers Do
label: Thesongsays
description: Seattle producer crafts an immersive and artful album that juggles house music's tropes to create a vast, rich world.

title: New Heaven
label: Frenchkiss
description: Pittsburgh duo's debut shows a depth and breadth of songwriting that hints at better things to come.

title: City Limits Volume 2
label: Deep Medi
description: Silkie follows up his 2009 debut with a sophomore effort that's simultaneously nostalgic and contemporary.

title: James Drake
label: self-released
description: Two Philly-based producers start with a pun on the names of Drake and James Blake and finish with a surprisingly effective mixtape.

title: Goodbye Bread
label: Drag City
description: On his first full-length for Drag City, the SF-based garage rocker slows down but doesn't mellow out while demonstrating growth as a songwriter along the way.

title: Realism
label: Cascine
description: Finnish duo's backward-leaning pop songs are deeply committed to the allure of dated sounds. Paula Abdul guests.

title: Twist Again
label: Thousand Tongues
description: After lineup changes and a side project, Music Go Music, the spirited L.A. band's third album signals a rebirth, but it's surprisingly somber and subdued.

title: Fiend Without a Face/West End Motel
label: Rocket Science
description: Mastodon guitarist's two outside projects, one newish and one long-running, are packaged here together as a value-priced two-fer.

title: Dr. Lecter
label: Fine Fabric Delegates
description: Up-and-coming Queens rapper releases a rock-solid, ridiculously fun album that recalls the past glories of New York rap without feeling derivative.

title: Bon Iver
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Justin's Vernon's project started out low-key and largely solo but has grown into an expansive and ambitious full-band affair with brilliant results.

title: In Vogue Spirit
label: De Stijl
description: On third album, Iowa noise-psych vets (formerly of Raccoo-oo-oon) temper their open-ended improv with the traditional stuff of rock.

title: Country Stash / What I Became
label: Three Lobed
description: Prolific Vermont duo rewards fans' patience with two new studio albums, featuring guests Jeremy Earl (Woods) and Andy Ramsay (Stereolab, High Llamas).

title: Plantation
label: self-released
description: This promising self-released record from a young singer-songwriter mixes grim and emotional songwriting with expansive electronic production.

title: Archives Performance Series Vol. 9: A Treasure
label: Reprise
description: The first Archives Performance Series entry to feature a less celebrated stretch of Young's career rescues his mid-80s country phase from its context.

title: Marissa Nadler
label: Box of Cedar
description: On her first album for her new label, the subtly devastating singer-songwriter continues her dark exploration of love and loss.

label: Fan Death
description: Ex-Clockcleaner singer John Sharkey III's solo project trades guitar spew for soaring synths, approaching the dramatic 1980s goth-pop of Bauhaus and the Cure.

title: Change Is Gradual
label: Sugarcane
description: On their second LP, Processory are among a growing faction of revivalists taking cues from the new romantic pop music of the 1980s.

title: Don't Blame the Stars
label: Misra
description: Returning to the LP abandoned after the death of violinist Noel Sayre, the Black Swans craft a quietly devastating album that showcases his mournful playing.

title: FRKWYS Vol. 6
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Fresh off her hypnotic LP The Magic Place, Barwick collaborates on a live set with experimental music vet Ikue Mori.

title: Deserter's Songs [Deluxe Edition]
label: V2
description: Mercury Rev's influential orchestral rock landmark from 1998 has been reissued in 2xCD form, with an extra disc of demos and rarities.

title: Ways of Meaning
label: Desire Path
description: Drone artist subtly drifts from the rougher, organic sounds of his past work to rounded, pillow-soft tones with the feel of cold, clear air.

title: The Errant Charm
label: Sub Pop
description: Andy Cabic's folk-rock project still has a way with good vibes and appealing arrangements on its fifth album.

title: Locussolus
label: International Feel
description: The long-time DJ and promoter's first full-length gathers 12" singles and remixes by Andrew Weatherall and Lindstrom & Prins Thomas.

title: Castlemania
label: In the Red
description: The latest installment from the prolific SF-based psych rockers finds frontman John Dwyer handling more of the instruments and taking the pace down a notch.

title: McCartney / McCartney II
label: Concord
description: Separated by a decade, the first two post-Beatles albums credited solely to Paul McCartney are a strange pair, but they shouldn't be overlooked.

title: Walls
label: Mom & Pop
description: At its best, this Australian duo brings to mind Sleater-Kinney's mix of plaintive vocals and ripping uptempo blur.

title: Are You Gonna Eat That?
label: Rhymesayers
description: This pleasantly low-stakes side project from cult MC Aesop Rock sounds like three guys making rap music and having fun doing it.

title: With U EP
label: Tri Angle
description: Holy Other's debut EP on the Tri Angle label uses tools common in the post-Burial witch house scene but manages some intriguing new twists.

title: An Empty Bliss Beyond This World
label: History Always Favours the Winners
description: James Leyland Kirby, the British producer also known for his work as V/Vm, returns as Caretaker with a haunting and gorgeous series of edits from old 78s.

title: Bakesale [Deluxe Edition]
label: Sub Pop
description: Sebadoh's most focused album, originally released in 1994, is given a deluxe 2xCD reissue with added singles and outtakes.

title: Earth Sound System
label: Fire
description: Latest from the long-running Portland collective maintains the group's experimental streak but loses some of the tension that defined its best work.

title: Clutching Stems
label: Merge
description: The Ladybug Transistor's seventh album brings together yet another iteration of the band's roster for a modest, pleasant indie-pop record.

title: Lobelia
label: Preservation
description: Working with guitar, banjo, electronics, and field recordings, this Wisconsin artist has crafted an immersing instrumental album flecked with surprises.

title: I Gotta Rokk EP
label: Island
description: Drawing singles from his forthcoming album, DJ Shadow's latest flirts with trendy, forward-thinking sounds in bass music without jumping into the thick of it.

title: It's All True
label: Domino
description: On their latest full-length, Junior Boys find a middle ground between the tricky production of their early work and later 1980s-indebted opulence.

title: These Trails
label: Drag City
description: Drag City reissues this lovely and evocative slice of Pacific folk-rock in a handsome new authorized edition.

title: Lonely Twin
label: Graveface
description: Having played with Shearwater and the Appleseed Cast, Jordan Geiger releases his second album of dense-yet-intimate psych-pop as Hospital Ships.

title: A Different Compilation
label: Cooking Vinyl
description: In a puzzling move, the legendary punk outfit re-records songs from throughout its career for what is indeed a different compilation.

title: iTunes Session
label: Mexican Summer
description: Drawing from Crazy For You and earlier singles and tossing in a cover, Bethany Cosentino takes a well-earned victory lap.

title: Arabia Mountain
label: Vice
description: Working with producer Mark Ronson to get the best 1960s-style production sound money can buy, Black Lips have crafted a very solid album.

title: Canta Lechuza
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: This Latin-tinged electro-folk project takes a rustic turn with intriguing results.

title: ISAM
label: Ninja Tune
description: Montreal producer's latest, a collaboration with London-based visual artist Tessa Farmer, abandons sampling in favor of altered bits of Tobin's own design.

title: Loud Planes Fly Low
label: Merge
description: A decade into its musical partnership, the indie pop duo crafts a transitional album focused on renewal.

title: An American Trilogy
label: Drag City
description: Newbury was a visionary country music outsider, and this collection brings together three albums and rarities from the late 1960s and early 70s.

title: Suck It and See
label: Domino
description: With Alex Turner's bleak sense of humor and agile lyrics-- and music that nods to Sabbath or the Stooges-- the Sheffield band continues to surprise.

title: Our Lives Are Shaped By What We Love: Motown's MoWest Story 1971-1973
label: Light in the Attic
description: This collection of obscurities from the ill-fated early-1970s Motown offshoot proves to be a surprisingly strong document of pre-disco pop and soul.

title: Iris
label: Rush Hour
description: The Dutch producer returns with a mix of techno and vocal house that is gorgeous on the surface but harder to crack on a deeper level.

title: Leisure Seizure
label: Island
description: Six years after his debut, the British producer crafts a follow up, losing some of his older work's post-punk tics but keeping an emphasis on rhythm.

title: Remixes 2: 81-11
label: Mute
description: A sequel of sorts to 2004's Remixes 81-04, this 3xCD set chronicles remixes from the band's last two albums, with a few old favorites for good measure.

title: David Comes to Life
label: Matador
description: Toronto's Fucked Up continue their outsized ambition with a lengthy rock opera featuring a twisted storyline and epic guitar-driven songs.

title: EAR PWR
label: Carpark
description: The spazzy electro-pop duo has moved from Baltimore to North Carolina and acquired a new, more mature sound.

title: Reflection
label: Post Present Medium
description: All-female cult punk group from D.C. is chronicled with this 12-song overview of its brief career, thanks to No Age's Dean Spunt's PPM imprint.

title: Larceny & Old Lace
label: Suicide Squeeze
description: Atlanta quartet's third album maintains the chaotic vitality of their previous records with a more polished sound.

title: Suede [Deluxe Edition] / Dog Man Star [Deluxe Edition]
label: Demon
description: Suede's first two albums, key documents of the music of 1990s Britain, are reissued with a generous helping of bonus material.

title: Gloss Drop
label: Warp
description: Tyondai Braxton and his distinct vocals have moved on, but Battles remain committed to making complex pop-prog sound like fun. Gary Numan guests.

title: Sondre Lerche
label: Tellé
description: On his self-titled seventh LP, Sondre Lerche nods to Brill Building formalism, 70s singer-songwriter fare, subdued bossa nova, and polite power pop.

title: Out on the Open West
label: Tompkins Square
description: The Fleet Foxes tourmate and old-time music practitioner follows an album of traditional tunes with a collection of his own songs.

title: Make Your Own Danger
label: Pentar
description: The Ukranian-American's latest incorporates coffeehouse singer/songwriter fare, lean, propulsive rock, and chamber instruments and hand percussion.

title: Absolute II
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Fiercely independent and with few avenues into its world, this minimalist record completes the psych-rock band's Thank Your Parents trilogy.

title: Cults
label: In the Name Of
description: Following their Internet hit "Go Outside", Cults prove they have the dexterity and songwriting to make a varied and memorable album.

title: Outbreeding
label: Brainlove
description: The singer-songwriter with a rich baritone and a skewed sense of humor makes his most band-oriented record.

title: Blow Your Head Vol. 2: Dave Nada Presents Moombahton
label: Mad Decent
description: On Diplo's Mad Decent label, DJ Dave Nada offers this overview of moombahton, a party-ready genre built from slowed-down samples of Dutch house records.

title: W
label: DFA
description: The Knife collaborator and multimedia artist establishes her own bold, sexually assertive identity on her DFA debut.

title: True Loves
label: Dovecote
description: Taking cues from the synth-pop spectrum and adding some arena-ready hooks, Hooray for Earth slot nicely alongside the psych-pop of MGMT and Yeasayer.

title: Channel Pressure
label: Software
description: The project from Joel Ford and Oneohtrix Point Never's Daniel Lopatin (formerly known as Games) shows a charming affection for the sounds of 1980s pop.

title: Blvcklvnd Rvdix 66.6 (1991)
label: self-released
description: This lo-fi opus from the young rapper/producer mixes Three 6 Mafia chanting, woozy Wu-Tang loops, DJ Screw wheeze, and Mortal Kombat sound effects.

title: Pre Serene: Thee Oneironauts
label: Home of the Rebels
description: Three members of the Most Serene Republic reach into the vaults to dust off their teenage, pre-Arts & Crafts recordings.

title: Bury Me in My Rings
label: Vagrant
description: Former Rilo Kiley member takes aim at the California lifestyle on his latest outing as the Elected.

title: Lupercalia
label: Mercury
description: Ambitious and heady as always, Patrick Wolf here takes a headfirst dive into new romantic pop.

title: Sun and Shade
label: Woodsist
description: Woods' latest is another solid record that finds them returning in spots to the experimental vein explored on earlier records and in their live show.

title: Bachelorette
label: Drag City
description: The third album from the New Zealand-bred electro-popper finds her continuing her mix of layered vocals and dense lyricism.

title: Zayna Jumma
label: Sublime Frequencies
description: This Western Saharan family act, who records for Sublime Frequencies, maintains the raw heart of its sound while moving away from its lo-fi roots.

title: Echolocations EP
label: R&S
description: This six-song EP feels very much like an extension of EFT, the electronic producer's last full-length. That proves to be a good thing.

title: Ukulele Songs
label: Monkeywrench
description: Just like it says on the box: The Pearl Jam frontman strums and sings simple love songs. Chan Marshall of Cat Power guests.

title: Codes and Keys
label: Atlantic
description: Death Cab are experimenting on their latest full-length, focusing less on tunes and melody and more on electronic sound.

title: Charade Is Gold
label: Audraglint
description: The Chicago electronic outfit moves from tech-focused glitch pop to a darker 80s sound with generally positive results.

title: Everything's Getting Older
label: Chemikal Underground
description: Arab Strap's Aidan Moffat teams with fellow Scottish music vet multi-instrumentalist Bill Wells to tackle aging, mundanity, and insecurity.
